Review Recent advances of the catalysts for photoelectrocatalytic oxygen evolution and CO2 reduction reactions Hong-Rui Zhu Hui-Min Xu Chen-Jin Huang Zhi-Jie Zhang Qi-Ni Zhan Ting-Yu Shuai Gao-Ren Li * College of Materials Science and Engineering, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, Sichuan, China College of Materials Science and Engineering Sichuan University Chengdu Sichuan 610065 China College of Materials Science and Engineering, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, Sichuan, China * Corresponding author. Increasing global energy consumption and environmental pollution make the use of new energy sources and environmentally friendly technologies essential to meet the diverse needs of industries. Photoelectrocatalysis is a promising method of utilising solar and electrical energy for various catalytic reactions with significant environmental and energy saving benefits. And photoelectrocatalytic (PEC) oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) are two catalytic reactions with great potential for energy and environmental applications. PEC OER is critical for renewable energy technologies for water oxidation and other related oxidation reactions. PEC CO2RR converts carbon dioxide into high-value products via a catalyst, enabling the rational use of carbon dioxide and the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. Both technologies are efficient, environmentally friendly, and sustainable. However, further research and optimisation are needed to promote the industrial application of both technologies for energy conversion and environmental protection. This paper reviews the research progress of PEC CO2RR and OER catalysts in recent years, including detailed descriptions of catalyst types, reaction mechanisms and performance tests. Finally, the paper considers the future trends and prospects of PEC technology, providing new insights into the technology and research directions for PEC OER and CO2RR catalysts. Graphical Abstract Photoelectrocatalysis (PEC) technology combines the features of photocatalytic and electrocatalytic technologies. Under the synergistic effect of photoelectricity, an oxygen evolution reaction occurs at the photoanode, i.e. oxygen is produced by splitting water through light and electric energy. On the surface of the photocathode, a CO2 reduction reaction occurs, resulting in different and high value-added products. This paper focuses on the facilitating role of PEC technology in these two catalytic reactions and its prospects for industrial application and research value. Keywords Photoelectrocatalysis Catalyst design Catalyst fabrication Oxygen evolution reaction CO2 reduction reaction 1 Introduction Soil, air, water, and fire are the four basic substances that make up the world, and they are essential for the development of human society and the use of energy. Humans can mine coal, oil and other fuels from the soil to generate electricity, as well as utilise wind and tidal energy. Fire was the earliest source of energy and heat used by mankind, and in modern times it has become the medium for most energy conversion, for example, by burning fossil fuels to generate electricity. After entering the 21st century, electric energy in the world as a major source of energy, applied to all aspects of human social production. With the rapid development of science and technology, mankind has been able to generate electricity through various energy conversion to meet the growing demand. With more and more in-depth research on electric energy, catalysis using electric energy has been widely used in various fields, such as electrocatalytic decomposition of water, reduction of CO2, conversion of small molecules and organic compounds, fuel cells, etc. [ 1–10 ]. However, in addition to the above four substances, there is another kind of energy that has been used since the birth of human society, and the utilization rate still cannot be effectively improved until today, and this energy is solar energy. With the gradual development of science and technology, light energy has also been gradually valued [ 11–25 ]. In 1905, Albert Einstein successfully explained the photoelectric effect and won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921, which provides theoretical basis for the mechanism of photoelectrocatalytic reactions. In 1967, Akira Fujishima discovered that when titanium oxide single crystals in water were irradiated with ultraviolet lamps, the water was decomposed into oxygen and hydrogen, thus triggering research into photolysis of water. This discovery successfully pioneered research in the field of photocatalysis and laid the cornerstone for the use of solar energy in catalysis, accelerated the research and use of solar energy by researchers. Solar energy has two main advantages: (1) solar energy is the most widely used of all renewable energy sources (i.e., wind, hydroelectric, tidal and ocean currents, geothermal, biomass and solar); (2) other pollutants such as CO, CO2, sulfide, and other pollutants are not produced [ 26–45 ]. Photocatalytic reactions using solar energy have been studied for nearly 50 years [ 46 ]. It has the characteristics of energy saving, environmental protection, and can be applied in many fields [ 47–49 ], with a large potential for development [ 50–54 ]. It should be noted that electrical energy is always a secondary energy source, which always requires other energy transformations, whereas light energy is a primary energy source, which means that it can be utilised directly without the need for transformations in other media [ 55 ]. However, current photocatalysts have various drawbacks that limit their large-scale industrialisation. Firstly, most photocatalysts perform well under ultraviolet light, and their performance decreases significantly under visible light, which is not in line with the original intention of using natural light for catalytic reactions. The use of UV light in industrial production will increase the production cost and technical difficulty. Secondly, up to now, the reaction conditions and performance evaluation standards of photocatalysis still cannot reach unity, such as the solution type, pH value and catalyst dosage of the reaction system. Most importantly, the reaction efficiency of most photocatalysts needs to be improved, and the light absorption capacity and catalytic activity of photocatalysts are still not able to meet the demands of industrial production. Electrocatalytic technology has a larger reaction efficiency compared to photocatalysis and has been used in many industrial applications [ 56,57 ]. Therefore, in the use of electrical energy for effective catalytic reactions, the moderate use of light energy to reduce the consumption of electrical energy will become the mainstream tendency of energy use in the future [ 58 ]. Photoelectrocatalysis technology combines the advantages of photocatalytic and electrocatalytic technologies to maximize the use of light and electrical energy [ 59–70 ]. It has attracted a lot of attention due to wide application prospects, low cost of use and environmental friendliness [ 71–80 ]. Compared to photocatalysis, the photoelectrocatalytic (PEC) reactions use sunlight irradiation to generate photogenerated electrons at the photoelectric electrode, which enhances reaction activity and catalytic efficiency [ 81–85 ]. Compared to electrocatalysis, PEC reactions significantly reduce the need for external energy injection, resulting in reduced energy consumption and environmental pollution [ 86–99 ]. In addition, PEC allows the use of catalysts that are unsuitable for photocatalysis due to energy band structure mismatch, under suitable applied voltage conditions (Scheme 1 ) [ 100–102 ]. PEC reactions cover a variety of processes, including OER, organic pollutant degradation, carbon dioxide reduction and nitrogen reduction for ammonia synthesis, depending on the reactant and reaction type. Among the various catalytic reactions, PEC OER and PEC CO2RR have significant research value and promising prospects as they achieve the dual goals of energy conversion and carbon resource utilization by utilizing clean energy [ 103 ]. Key determinants that influence PEC reaction systems include their light adsorption capacity, charge transport and transfer characteristics, and the availability of surface-active sites [ 104 ]. Addressing these challenges necessitates the design of high-performance and stable systems [ 89,105–115 ]. PEC OER, driven by solar and electrical energy, is a catalytic reaction that oxidizes water to produce oxygen [ 5,72 ]. Compared to conventional electrochemical oxygen evolution reactions, photoelectrocatalytic OER offers several advantages. Firstly, it harnesses renewable solar energy as an energy source, mitigating the reliance on fossil fuels and the associated environmental concerns. Secondly, photoelectrocatalytic OER reduces the need for external electrical energy supply, thereby minimizing energy losses and electrode corrosion commonly observed in traditional electrochemical reactions. Typical photoanode catalysts, such as BiVO4, TiO2, and Fe2O3, have been extensively studied to enhance the performance of PEC OER and drive further research in this field [ 26,105 ]. These PEC catalysts all have several characteristics: (1) Excellent light absorption, especially for the visible light range. (2) High carrier separation efficiency, which will make the photogenerated holes efficiently enter the reaction system and thus enhance the catalytic activity. (3) Well conductivity, which is the basic condition for the good catalytic activity of the PEC OER. (4) Excellent adsorption of the reactive species. PEC CO2 Reduction Reaction (CO2RR) is a catalytic reaction driven using solar and electrical energy to convert carbon dioxide into CO or other high-value products [ 116,117 ]. The PEC CO2RR reaction offers several advantages. Firstly, it can utilize renewable solar energy as an energy source to achieve resourceful use of CO2 and reduce greenhouse gas emissions, thereby combating climate change [ 118,119 ]. Secondly, PEC CO2RR can effectively utilize clean energy while reducing electrical energy consumption during the catalytic process. Furthermore, PEC CO2RR allows for the selective synthesis of various high-value products by adjusting the catalyst's composition and structure, including formic acid, ethylene, ethanol, and acetic acid. Previous research has demonstrated that copper-based catalysts possess exceptional CO2 adsorption properties and stability, resulting in high CO2 conversion efficiencies. Moreover, metal nitrides and porphyrin-based materials have been extensively investigated in PEC CO2RR reactions. Like the catalysts used for PEC OER, catalysts with excellent PEC CO2RR activity need to have the advantages of high photogenerated electron-hole pair separation efficiency, excellent electrical conductivity, and good light absorption. The difference is that PEC CO2RR needs to have good adsorption of CO2 to have higher selectivity in the electrolyte. From the catalyst point of view, traditional catalysts often have the disadvantages of being expensive (e.g., using precious metals such as Au, Ag, Cu, Pt, Pd, etc.), complicated synthesis methods, and low reaction efficiency. This leads to high production costs and complex technological routes for the industrial application of conventional catalysts, which is not conducive to meeting the challenges of future developments. Catalysts for PEC OER and CO2RR are characterised by simple synthesis methods, environmental friendliness, high reaction efficiency, stability, and recyclability. This is one of the more striking aspects in today's catalytic industry. When the production cost of PEC catalysts is controlled, large-scale industrial applications can be realised. Previous reviews have reported only PEC OER or PEC CO2RR, and few reviews have reported both PEC OER and PEC CO2RR. We believe that in a photoelectrocatalytic system, the photoanode can undergo an oxidation reaction while the photocathode can undergo a reduction reaction, and if the cathode and anode can be utilised at the same time, it will greatly improve the efficiency of the cathode and anode utilisation in the PEC system. Therefore, PEC OER and PEC CO2RR, which are two reactions with industrial applications, were selected among many reactions for review. In the photoelectrocatalytic system, the photoelectric anode can be used for PEC OER and the photoelectric cathode can be used for PEC CO2RR, which can maximise the use of photoelectrocatalytic technology in industrial production to achieve energy saving and environmental protection. In conclusion, investigating PEC CO2RR and OER holds immense scientific significance and application. By delving into the intricacies of catalysts and catalytic mechanisms inherent in diverse materials, novel avenues can be unveiled to address the imperatives of sustainable energy generation and environmental conservation. This review comprehensively covers recent research progress on PEC CO2RR and OER mechanisms. Finally, this review envisions the future development trends and prospects of PEC technology. It provides a quick and accessible way to understand the technology and offers a reference point for the study of PEC OER and CO2RR. 2 Photoelectrocatalytic OER 2.1 Basic principles of PEC OER During the PEC OER reaction, light excites the active sites on the catalyst surface, reducing the overpotential at high current densities and making industrialisation possible [ 120,121 ]. The reaction that occurs is the same as OER under electrocatalytic conditions, but the solar energy injects additional energy into the reaction, which lowers the energy potential barrier required for the reaction and will reduce the amount of electrical energy required for the reaction and lower the overpotential (Table 1 ), where Eq. (1) is the total reaction process for OER, and Eqs. (2)–(5) are stepwise reactions of the OER reaction process. The PEC OER also follows a four-electron path, which is the same as the electrocatalytic OER. As shown in Scheme 2 , the adsorption of active species is particularly important for the PEC OER reaction. And during the adsorption of active species, different decision steps are shown for different reaction systems. Currently, there are many known methods that can change the adsorption energy of PEC systems for active species, such as doping other elements, creating vacancies, forming amorphous states, and creating heterojunctions. The core elements of these methods are: (1) altering the band gap of the catalyst to make it easier for photogenerated electrons to spill over the surface of the catalyst; (2) changing the electrical conductivity of the catalyst to accelerate the migration rate of photogenerated carriers; (3) altering the d/p band center of the main adsorption site, which will facilitate the adsorption of intermediates; (4) changing the light absorption capacity of the catalyst surface, some systems will be covered with a layer of dye-sensitised material on the surface, which will greatly enhance the light absorption capacity of the system. It should be noted that the PEC OER process, when the light can provide enough energy, the system can break through the decisive beam step limitation of the catalytic process, and even break through the theoretical overpotential under some electrolyte systems. It is since in the PEC OER process, the active species are not only OH–, but also ·OH, photogenerated holes h+, etc., and the synergistic effect of these active species accelerates the catalytic reaction and improves the efficiency of the reaction. 2.2 Catalyst design principles for PEC OER In fact, for the OER reaction, both photocatalytic and electrocatalytic techniques have been used to carry out a lot of research work on it. Especially for electrocatalytic OER, many related reactions have been industrialised. However, the electrocatalytic OER process is still deeply plagued by the complex four-electron step, which makes it very difficult to reduce the high overpotential in OER reactions. Therefore, breaking through the energy limitation of the four-electron step by combining other catalytic methods (e.g., light, heat, and enzyme) to reduce the overpotential is the future development direction for exploring electrocatalytic OER. In addition, the industrialisation of electrocatalytic OER requires a high current density, and the energy of this high current density requires a large amount of energy source supply, which is detrimental to the industrialization of the production cost, and increases the risk of environmental pollution, which is not in line with the concept of “green chemistry” [ 122,123 ]. In contrast, the reaction steps of the photocatalytic OER process are like those of electrocatalytic OER, except that the active species in it is ·OH. Meanwhile, the evaluation criteria for the performance of photocatalytic OER are different from those of electrocatalytic systems. Photocatalytic OER is based on the detection of the reaction system by gas chromatography, to calculate the concentration of oxygen evolution, while comparing the apparent quantum efficiency as the evaluation criterion of catalytic activity. During the reaction process, the sacrificial agent needs to be added to formulate a homogeneous solution used to absorb the photogenerated electrons to ensure that they do not interfere with the OER process, allowing the photogenerated holes to combine with H2O to produce more ·OH. Meanwhile, the recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs is hindered to improve the photocatalytic OER activity. However, the rate of photogenerated holes production is too slow under light conditions, resulting in ·OH concentrations that are far from sufficient for application in practical production. In summary, although photocatalytic OER will greatly reduce the pollution caused to the environment, however, due to the incomplete technical conditions, its industrial production still needs a lot of research work to overcome the technical drawbacks of photocatalytic OER. In view of this, photoelectrocatalytic technology, which combines the advantages and overcomes the disadvantages of photocatalysis and electrocatalysis, has emerged. The purpose of using PEC technology is to be able to effectively reduce the consumption of electrical energy and reduce the energy consumption required for catalytic reactions [ 124,125 ]. Meanwhile, minimize the scale of use of fossil fuels in industrial production, thereby reducing the pollution caused to the environment. Therefore, the selection of materials with good photosensitivity and electrocatalytic activity at the same time became the focus of PEC OER. First, choosing materials with good photosensitivity helps to generate more photogenerated electrons, which improves the reaction activity and catalytic efficiency. However, materials with excellent photosensitivity and electrocatalytic activity are not common, so it is necessary to modify the materials to have excellent PEC OER performance. Examples include doping with other elements, creating vacancies or other defects, and compounding with other materials to form heterojunctions [ 71,126,127 ]. 2.3 Synthesis methods of catalysts for PEC OER The common synthesis methods of catalysts used for PEC OER are: impregnation, spin-coating, calcination sedimentation, and hydrothermal, etc. The impregnation method involves the impregnation of liquids containing active substances into various types of carriers. After the impregnation equilibrium is reached, the excess liquid is removed, and the target catalysts are finally obtained after subsequent treatments such as drying. Spin-coating is a widely used technique for preparing catalysts on substrates (FTO glass mainly). The principle is to drop a solution containing materials and solvents onto a rotating substrate and use the combined effect of centrifugal force and surface tension to make the solution synthesise catalysts on the substrate. Calcination is a heat treatment process, often occurring in tube furnaces or other apparatus where high temperature reactions can take place, which can be used to synthesise catalysts or change their structure and properties. Deposition methods refer to techniques used to deposit or coat catalyst materials onto a substrate or support material. These methods are crucial in creating catalysts with specific properties tailored for desired reactions. Deposition methods mainly include chemical vapour deposition, atomic layer deposition, electrodeposition, photodeposition, etc. Hydrothermal method mainly occurs in a sealed reactor, using water or other liquid reagents as solvents to synthesise catalysts under high temperature and pressure, the catalysts synthesised are often in powder form, and some catalysts on substrates are also synthesised by hydrothermal method. 2.4 Configuration of PEC OER In typical PEC water oxidation cell, there exist single electrolyzer and double electrolyzer. The common reaction system is a three-electrode system in which the working electrode is a photoanode, and common photoanode materials include hydroxyl oxide, BiVO4, α-Fe2O3, etc. While Pt electrode or graphite electrode is used as counter electrode in single electrolyzer, other photocathode materials are used as counter electrode in double electrolyzer. The reference electrode is commonly Hg/HgO or Ag/AgCl [ 85 ]. 2.5 Evaluate the parameters of PEC OER performance The common measurement methods in PEC OER studies include linear sweep voltammetry (LSV), chronoamperometry (i-t), or chrono-potentiometry (v-t) under dark or irradiated conditions, etc. Key parameters performance of PEC OER photoanodes include current density (j ph), overpotentials at different current densities, Tafel slope, impedance values, etc. In addition, the following parameters are used as important evaluation criteria, and we have also listed the relevant calculation formulas. STH efficiency is one of the important parameters commonly used to evaluate the performance of PEC OER. STH defines the overall solar conversion efficiency of a zero/self-biased two-electrode PEC OER cell and is commonly used as a benchmark for evaluating the performance of PEC OER cells. The definition of STH efficiency for PEC OER as shown in Eq. (1) [ 85 ]: (1) S T H = [ | J s c | × 1.23 ( V ) × ϕ F p ] A M 1.5 G where J sc (mA cm–2) is photocurrent density of the PEC OER, Ø F is the Faraday efficiency of electrochemical H2 evolution, and P (mW cm–2) is the incident light power density. The conversion efficiency of the photoelectrode is usually expressed thermodynamically using the applied bias photon current conversion efficiency (ABPE) (Eq. (2)) [ 85 ]. (2) A B P E = [ | J l i g h t | × ( 1.23 - V l i g h t ) p ] A M 1.5 G where J light is the measured photocurrent density and V light (vs. RHE) is the applied bias at this current density. Recently, the solar-to-chemical conversion efficiency (ISTC) of the photovoltaic electrode was presented by extracting (Eq. (3)) from the LSV results [ 85 ]. (3) I S T C = 1.23 ( V R H E ) × ϕ F V d a r k ( V R H E ) [ J p h o t o × V p h o t o p ] A M 1.5 G where Ø F is the Faradic efficiency of the electrochemical reaction assumed to be 100%, J photo (mA cm–2) = J light – J dark is the difference between light and dark photocurrent density, V dark is the applied voltage to attain the dark current density equals J photo, V photo (V) = V light – V dark is the photovoltage at a certain value of J photo, and P (mW cm–2) is the power density of the incident light. 2.6 Classification of PEC catalysts suitable for OER In the following, we will describe the classification of common materials used for PEC OER. Analyzed in terms of structural composition, common PEC OER catalysts can be classified into six types: oxides, nitrides, sulfide, polymers, carbon-based and MOF catalysts (Fig. 1 ) [ 73,86,128,129 ]. 2.6.1 Metal oxide catalysts The excellent photocatalytic and electrocatalytic properties of oxide materials and the existence of bandgap tunability make it possible to adjust the bandgap on the surface of inorganic materials by doping, forming defects, and synthesizing various kinds of heterojunctions, making it easier for electrons to jump from valence to conduction bands, thus enhancing the overall performance. Common oxide materials for PEC OER include TiO2, hydroxyl oxides, BiVO4, α-Fe2O3, etc. [ 35,130–134 ]. BiVO4, as an n-type photocatalyst, has excellent hole conductivity. The band gap of BiVO4 is ≈2.4 eV and absorbs light below 520 nm, resulting in a theoretical photocurrent density of ≈7.5 mA cm–2. The hole diffusion length of BiVO4, determined by time-resolved microwave conductivity (TRMC) analysis, is calculated to be 70 nm. It shows better hole conductivity compared to Fe2O3 (2–5 nm) but is shorter than WO3 (150–500 nm). BiVO4 is stable during water oxidation, does not undergo self-oxidation, and exhibits moderate stability in a neutral environment with pH range of 3–10 [ 135–138 ]. Song et al. [ 139 ] synthesized NiFeOOH/MoO x /MQD/BiVO4 photoanodes for PEC OER. The addition of MoO x /MQD as a hole transport layer slows down the charge complexation, promotes hole transport, accelerates the water splitting kinetics, and significantly improves the water oxidation activity of the PEC (Fig. 2(a) ). Fig. 2(b) shows that the NiFeOOH/MoO x /MQD/ BiVO4 photoanode has the highest photocurrent density among all the samples. Notably, the photocurrent densities of NiFeOOH/MoO x /MQD/BiVO4 photoanodes reached 3.82, 4.68, and 5.85 mA cm–2 at 0.6, 0.8, and 1.23 V vs. RHE, respectively (Figs. 2(b) and 2(c)) suggesting that the MoO x /MQD and NiFeOOH layers have a strong influence on porous. The ABPE of the prepared NiFeOOH/MoO x /MQD/BiVO4 photoanode reached recorded value of 2.43% at 0.58 V vs. RHE, higher than that of the previously reported photoanode (Figs. 2(d) and 2(e)). Figs. 2(f) and 2(g) show the carrier transfer process of the composites during the PEC OER process. The composites with co-catalysts have better performance since they could greatly accelerate the carrier transfer rate. Song and coworkers [ 140 ] constructed integrated Co-agZIF-62/NiO/MO photoanodes on semiconductor substrates with different metal oxides (MO: Fe2O3, WO3 and BiVO4). Co-based zeolite imidazolium salt skeleton, Co-ZIF-62, was synthesized using mechanochemical methods (Fig. 2(h)). The photocurrent density of the 10% Co-agZIF-62/BiVO4 photoanode was found to be the highest based on LSV curves (Fig. 2(i)). (Fig. 2(j)). At 0.74 V vs. RHE, the Co-agZIF-62/NiO/BiVO4 photoanode achieved maximum ABPE up to 1.67% (Fig. 2(k)). Yoon et al. [ 144 ] investigated the effect of Sn migration in germanium tin co doping system on its overall photovoltaic characteristics using Ge. The synthesis of pristine α-Fe2O3 and Ge-doped Fe2O3 (Ge-H) photoanodes is shown in Fig. 4(g). Fig. 4(h) shows the LSV curves in different solutions. The charge separation efficiency can be calculated based on the results of Fig. 4(h), and it indicates that the charge transfer efficiency of Ge-PH is the highest among all the samples (Fig. 4(i)). In conclusion, metal oxides have great potential as photoelectrocatalytic materials for energy transition and environmental protection. By rationally designing the energy band structure and surface properties of the materials, metal oxides can achieve efficient light adsorption and photogenerated charge separation, promoting the photoelectrocatalytic reaction. Furthermore, the catalytic activity and selectivity of metal oxides can be further enhanced by introducing co-catalysts and optimizing carrier transport pathways. With further research and engineering improvements, metal oxides are expected to become commercially viable and sustainable for practical applications in renewable energy and green chemistry. 2.6.2 Metal nitrides catalysts Metal Nitrides are widely used in PEC because of their high photoelectric properties, and common nitrides are GaN, Ta3N5, etc. The diffusion length of Ta3N5 is ∼103 nm, indicating a long lifetime of photogenerated charges. In addition, Ta3N5 possesses excellent photocatalytic activity, suggesting that photogenerated carriers can be efficiently separated in Ta3N5 crystals. In addition, the excellent light adsorption ability of Ta3N5 has led to its extensive study, with solar energy conversion efficiencies of up to 15% under AM 1.5 G sunlight [ 121,145–151 ]. Li's group fabricated particulate Ta3N5 photoanodes using a bottom-up approach [ 152 ]. The top view of the SEM image shows that after treatment with TaCl5 solution (Fig. 5(b) ), the surface of the porous material Ta3N5 (Fig. 5(a)) is covered by an amorphous layer. However, after neck contraction, the photoelectrochemical properties of these samples vary greatly (Fig. 5(c)). The results indicate that both untreated Ta3N5 and TaCl5 exhibit smaller photoelectric properties. But on necked Ta3N5, its optical current increases from 9 to 1.56 mA cm–2. Adding CoPi and other co-catalysts to necked Ta3N5 can significantly improve its catalytic performance, with an optimal current of 6.1 mA cm–2 (vs. RHE). Liu and coworkers [ 153 ] demonstrated an efficient photoanode system Ni(OH) x /Fh/Ta3N5(P). Compared with RHE, the Ta3N5 photoanode performance of this device reaches 12.1 mA cm–2 under 1.23 V conditions, which has reached the theoretical upper limit of photocurrent under solar irradiation (12.9 mA cm–2). Fig. 5(e) and f are HRTEM images of Ta3N5 and Ta3N5 (P) photoanodes. The prepared nickel hydroxide/tantalum fluoride (P) is an ideal optoelectronic active material, and its current to potential curve is shown in Fig. 5(g). The synthesized Ni(OH) x /Fh/Ta3N5(P) has the best photovoltaic performance (Fig. 5(g)). The onset potential of the photocurrent of Ni(OH) x /Fh/Ta3N5 (P) was around 0.55 V and up to 6.8 mA cm–2 at 1.23 V. The method of integrating the Ta3N5 (P) photoanode system is shown in Fig. 5(h). In the range of 0.6–1.0 V, the photocurrent rapidly increases, ultimately obtaining a photocurrent of 12.1 mA cm–2 (Fig. 5(i)), which is close to the maximum performance of Ta3N5 under sunlight (12.9 mA cm–2). Xiao et al. [ 154 ] used gradient doped magnesium for energy band structure engineering and defect control in Ta3N5. The gradient-doped Mg-based Ta3N5 photoanode has a low metal potential of 0.4 V and a high applied bias photon current efficiency of 3.25 ± 0.05% vs. RHE. The HRTEM image in Fig. 6(a) shows that the lattice fringes of Ta3N5 do not change significantly after doping, and the clear lattice fringes in Fig. 6(b) indicate that the internal crystallinity of the grains is highly desirable. Fig. 6(c) indicates that the onset potential moves towards the cathode as the concentration of Mg doping gradually increases. The increase in the photocurrent density of Mg: Ta3N5 is not significant, but there is a significant increase in the filling factor of the J-V curve. Fig. 6(d) shows the wavelength dependence of NiCoFe-Bi/gradient-Mg: Ta3N5/Nb IPCE values measured at 1.0 V VRHE. NiCoFe-Bi/gradient-Mg:Ta3N5/Nb reaches a maximum ABPE of 3.31% (Fig. 6(e)). Hybrid Ta3N5 nanorods and films on transparent GaN/Al2O3 substrates were developed by Pihosh and coworkers [ 155 ]. The synthesized photoanodes achieved a current density of 10.8 mA cm–2 at a voltage of 1.23 V compared to reversible hydrogen electrodes under simulated AM 1.5G solar illumination. The SEM and HAADF-STEM images in Fig. 6(f) and (g) indicate the formation of Ta3N5-NR on Ta3N5-TF/GaN/Al2O3 substrate. The prepared samples were loaded with FeNiCoO x catalysts by photoelectrodeposition (PED) and dip-coating methods, and the surfaces of Ta3N5-NRs were covered with a layer of FeNiCoO x cocooning catalyst (Fig. 6(h)). Fig. 6(i) shows the schematic design of Ta3N5 photoanode and PEC-PV tandem devices in three-electrode and two-electrode configurations. The current potential (J-V a) characteristics of the Ta3N5 photoanode on optically and electrically optimised 150 nm thick Ta3N5-tf (Fig. 6(j)) indicate that the onset potential Von for water oxidation is 0.75 VRHE (corresponding to J = 0.8 mA cm–2). Above V on, J rises sharply with increasing Va, reaching 10.5 mA cm–2 at 1.23 VRHE. Fig. 6(k) illustrates that the average STH energy conversion efficiency for hydrogen and oxygen (stoichiometric ratio of 2:1) was 11.07% for nearly 7 h. Higashi and coworkers [ 156 ] synthesised transparent Ta3N5 on n-type GaN/sapphire substrates to improve PEC OER performance. As illustrated in Fig. 7(a) , the resulting film is reddish in color and highly transparent. Fig. 7(b) illustrates SEM images of a Ta3N5/GaN/Al2O3 film, indicating that the film has a nanocrystalline structure consisting of several hundred nanometer-sized Ta3N5 crystals. Fig. 7(c) shows the current-potential (i-E) curves of NiFeO x /Ta3N5/GaN/Al2O3 transparent photoanodes, indicating that the initial potential is about 0.65 V. Fig. 7(d) shows the half-cell solar-hydrogen conversion efficiency (HC-STH) curves for NiFeO x /Ta3N5/GaN/Al2O3 photoanodes, indicating that the maximum value of HC-STH was 1.15% at 0.94 V vs. RHE. Fig. 7(e) indicates that the photoanode produces a photocurrent at 600 nm, proving that the wavelength of the absorption edge of Ta3N5 is 600 nm. At a wavelength of 420 nm and a voltage of 1.2 V vs. RHE, the IPCE value was 66%, while at wavelengths of 500 and 580 nm, the IPCE values were 48% and 14%, respectively. It has been reported that the current-potential characteristics of Ta3N5-NR photoanodes have been evaluated by developing a detailed photovoltaic modeling [ 157 ]. The XRD spectra indicate that the diffraction peaks of both Ta3N5-NRs and Ba: Ta3N5-NRs samples are associated with monoclinic Ta3N5 (Fig. 7(g)). The SEM images in Figs. 7(h)–(k) show that the vertical alignment of Ta3N5 NR photoanodes remains unchanged after doping with Ba. The current-potential (J-V) curves obtained under chopped AM 1.5G simulated solar radiation show that the photocurrent density at 1.23 VRHE (J a) increases by 72% from 3.2 to 5.5 mA cm–2 after doping barium elements in Ta3N5-NRs photoanodes. However, the onset potential (V ON) at 0.6 VRHE was unchanged, and the fill factor (FF) decreased slightly from 30% to 23% (Fig. 7(l)). Fig. 7(m) shows that barium doping in Ta3N5-NRs photoanodes increases the value by 31%, thereby increasing the maximum HC-STH efficiency η max from 0.58% to 0.76%. Fig. 7(n) illustrates that the Ba:Ta3N5-NRs photoanode has a relatively high IPCE value of 40%–48% in the 550 nm wavelength range compared to the Ta3N5-NRs photoanode. Fig. 7(o) shows that the barium-doped sample exhibits a lower solar energy loss in OER activity at 1.23 VRHE compared to the undoped material. Metal nitrides have excellent light-absorbing properties and electron-transporting ability, which can efficiently absorb light energy and achieve photogenerated charge separation. In addition, the stability and catalytic activity of metal nitrides make them ideal photoelectrocatalytic materials with a large future. 2.6.3 Metal sulfide catalysts Sulfide materials have tunable properties that may enable abundant catalytic active sites for light adsorption, charge transfer and solar-chemical energy conversion. Wang and coworkers developed a three-dimensional plate geometry ternary metal sulfide (CdIn2S4) [ 158 ]. Fig. 8(a) presents schematic diagram of the synthesis process of CdIn2S4 with S defects. The SEM images of Vs-CIS-500 are shown in Fig. 8(b), and its geometry is plate-like. The J-V plot shows that at 1.23 V vs. RHE, the photocurrent density of Vs-CIS-500 reaches 6 times that of pure CdIn2S4 (Fig. 8(c)). Vs-CIS-500 shows extremely high photon adsorption values (Fig. 8(d)), reaching a maximum ABPE of 2.49% at 0.477 V vs. RHE. The IPCE value of the CdIn2S4 photoanode is significantly increased in the light range of 350–500 nm, and the light that produces a measurable photovoltage is truncated between 525–550 nm, while the Vs-CIS-500 photoanode extends up to ~650 nm (Fig. 8(e)). Giri's group [ 159 ] synthesized vertically aligned SnS2 nanoflakes with good catalytic activity directly on transparent conducting substrates using a callable space sublimation (CSS) method. The synthesized materials have different dss at different temperatures, only the sample with source-substrate separation (dss) = 10 and the best catalytic activity is shown here with SEM image as shown in Fig. 8(f). The PEC performance was measured by LSV in different electrolytes for comparison (Fig. 8(g)). Under AM1.5G light conditions at 1.23 VRHE, maximum photocurrents of 4.5 mA cm–2 were generated in phosphate buffer + 1 mol L–1 Na2SO3 and 2.6 mA cm–2 in 0.5 mol L–1 Na2SO4 without the use of Na2SO3 hole scavengers. The IPCE (Fig. 8(h)) measured in the light of 0.1 mol L–1 KI + 1 mol L–1 H2SO4 at a fixed voltage of 0.6 VRHE shows that the optimized SnS2 nanosheets have an excellent ability to absorb and generate photocurrents. The result indicates that the photocurrent and durability are improved by about 4 and 10 times, respectively (Fig. 9(a) ). As indicated in Fig. 9(d), the photocurrent of CdS@CdIn2S4 NFA at 1 V vs. RHE reaches 5.5 mA cm–2, which is nearly twice as high as that of CdS NFA (2.7 mA cm–2) for both samples under 1 Sun AM1.5G illumination. The estimated photoelectric conversion efficiency is shown in Fig. 9(e). TiO2/CdS/MoS2 heterojunctions were prepared by Bhat et al. [ 161 ]. Fig. 9(f) illustrates schematic representation of the synthesized composites. Figs. 9(g) and (h) demonstrate SEM images of TiO2 NRs on FTO. And the maximum photocurrent density of TiO2/CdS/MoS2 at 0.9 V vs. RHE (0 V vs. Ag/AgCl) is 3.45 mA cm–2. The photocorrosion of CdS was inhibited by plating a thin layer of ZnS on TiO2/CdS/MoS2. The TiO2/CdS/MoS2 photoanode in Fig. 9(j) still maintains a good stability of the photocurrent density (0.2 mA cm–2) during the first 60 min. It is noteworthy that the IPCE spectra agree with the corresponding absorbance spectra (Figs. 9(k) and (l)). Metal sulfides possess good light-absorbing ability, capable of absorbing visible and near-infrared light. In addition, metal sulfides have good electron transport properties, which can effectively separate photo-excited electrons and holes, thus realizing efficient photogenerated charge separation. It means that sulfides have a broad research prospect in the field of PEC OER in the future. 2.6.4 Polymer-based catalysts Polymer materials are the class of organic materials with photovoltaic activity, which are widely used in the fields of organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs), organic transistors (OFETs), organic solar cells (OPVs), and new energy devices. The low cost of synthesizing polymer materials makes them attractive for functional and structural modification, as well as for their flexibility and film-forming properties. This has led to their use in the preparation of flexible and stretchable photovoltaic devices, which has caught the attention of researchers [ 20,140,162–169 ]. Cho and coworkers report a non-fullerene electron acceptor (NFA)-based, all-polymer BHJ photoanode (FTO/mZnO/BHJ/ PTAA/LIO) for PEC OER [ 170 ]. The molecular structures of the selected PDs and polymer receptors (PAs) are presented in Fig. 10(a) , and their energy level distributions are illustrated in Fig. 10(b). To improve the stability of the system, a mesoporous zinc oxide (mZnO) layer was added to the ETL structure (Fig. 10(c)). The LSV curve in Fig. 10(d) indicates that FTO/pZnO/BHJ has a sacrificial Jph of 3.5 mA cm–2 at 1.23 VRHE, with a negative shift in the onset potential to 0.35 VRHE. The IPCE spectral values measured at 1.23 VRHE exceeded 25% and were in good agreement with the BHJ adsorption spectra (Fig. 10(e)). More importantly, the PTAA layer greatly improves the operational stability (Fig. 10(f)). Sokol et al. [ 171 ] reported for PEC OER an unbiased semi-artificial tandem composite catalyst that connects photosystem II to hydrogenase. SEM images indicate that the TiO2 macropores have a diameter of 750 nm (Fig. 11(a) left). The components of the synthesized photoanode are shown in Fig. 11(a) right. The adsorption spectra of the co-sensitized IO-TiO2 electrodes show adsorption of panchromatic light (Fig. 11(b)). The synthesized photoanodes were dye-sensitized by soaking IO-TiO2 in tetrahydrofuran (THF) solution overnight (Fig. 11(c)). The step-potential timer was used under UV-filtered simulated sunlight (Fig. 11(d)) with periodic illumination. The current onset potential was about –0.5 V vs. SHE. A potential-independent photocurrent (80 μA cm–2) appeared when E app > –0.2 V vs. SHE (Fig. 11(e)), which was attributed to water oxidation. Conjugated organic polymers such as PM6 can also be used as photocatalysts, and their favorable light adsorption effect provides excellent results when performing PEC OER [ 172 ]. As illustrated in Fig. 12(a) , the PM6 film is wrapped around the surface of the InN NRs to form a core-shell structure, and a part of PM6 is loaded on the top of the NRs to accelerate the photogenerated electron migration rate. Fig. 12(b) illustrates the XRD spectrum of the InN nanorods. The results indicated that PM6 has obvious amorphous structure and does not appear obvious, and the loading of PM6 film did not affect the InN crystal structure. Meanwhile, the FTIR spectrum of PM6 also illustrates the characteristic peak of C (Fig. 12(c)) [ 173 ]. The LSV curves in Fig. 12(d) demonstrate that the modified InN/PM6 photocurrent density is 3.21 mA cm–2 at the same potential, which is 26 times higher than the photocurrent density of pure InN nanorods. Fig. 12(e) displays the optimal ABPE value of 0.66% for InN/PM6 photoanodes at 0.74 V compared to Ag/AgCl, which is a 15-fold increase compared to pristine InN. Whereas the NiFe LDH co-catalyst loaded composites showed 8.97% ABPE value at 0.78 V. In addition, the InN/PM6/NiFe LDH has the lowest impedance, indicating the most efficient charge transfer (Fig. 12(f)). Peng et al. [ 174 ] used p-type polyhexylthiophene (P3HT) as a hole-transporting layer (HTL) to enhance the photoelectrocatalytic activity of the material. The BiVO4/P3HT-CuPc/LDH photocurrent density reached 5.54 mA cm–2 at 1.23 VRHE due to the modulation of HTL. This work introduced doped P3HT as HTL into nico layered double hydroxide (LDH)-modified BiVO4 (BV) films to prepare BV/P3HT-cupc/LDH photoanodes, which were synthesized as shown in Fig. 12(g). The photocurrent densities of BV/LDH and BV/P3HT/LDH modified with NiCo-LDH were 1.75 and 2.28 times higher than those of BV under light conditions, which is a large improvement (Fig. 12(h)). When reacting in Na2SO3 solution (Fig. 12(i)), the BV/P3HT/LDH and BV/P3HT-cupc /LDH photocurrents were significantly better than those of the pristine BV or BV/LDH, which fully reflected the effect of the modification of P3HT HTL. Both IPCE (Fig. 12(j)) and ABPE (Fig. 12(k)) of BV/P3HT-CuPc/LDH were remarkably strengthened with respect to BV/P3HT/LDH. The ABPEmax of BV/P3HT-CuPc/LDH at 0.65 V was 1.36%, which was shifted negatively by 0.02 V with respect to BV/P3HT/LDH (Fig. 12(j)). In conclusion, polymer-based catalysts are of high research value. Firstly, polymer catalysts have a wide range of light-absorbing ability and a wide range of applications. Some polymer catalysts exhibit stability and corrosion resistance, making them suitable for use in harsh conditions. Additionally, certain polymer catalysts are renewable and degradable, thereby reducing their impact on the environment. 2.6.5 Carbon-based catalysts Carbon-based materials, mainly graphene, are flexible and highly conductive. It is commonly used as a substrate for synthesizing composite materials or wrapping other catalysts to form heterojunctions [ 175–178 ]. Yan and coworkers [ 179 ] utilized naphthalene to synthesize undoped or doped heteroatom GQDs in a bottom-up manner (Fig. 13(a) ). Their method effectively reduced the production cost (Fig. 13(b)), with a lattice spacing of 0.21 nm (Fig. 13(c)). Fig. 13(d) displays the current response of the NS-GQD/graphene electrode during PEC OER under solar energy. The HER performance and OER performance of the photoelectrochemical process are significantly higher than that of the pure electrochemical process. When ethanol containing 0.1 mol L–1 KOH was used as the reaction solution, the photocurrent response that appeared at the cathode was due to the action of photoexcited electrons only and was not related to the HER (Fig. 13(e)). By reducing the Schottky barrier, the photogenerated electron hole migration from nanocrystalline GQDs to graphene results in a significant exponential increase in the photoelectrochemical luminescence current of the anode electrode (Fig. 13(f)). As illustrated in Fig. 13(g), the properties of the synthesised photoanodes HER and OER remained extremely stable after 20 h. Zheng et al. [ 180 ] reported a photoanode made of a single-layer InSe crystal encapsulated by a single layer of graphene. Photocurrent with a density of 10 mA cm–2 at 1.23 VRHE was achieved. The synthesis principle is shown in Fig. 13(h). As illustrated in Fig. 13(i), the calculated chemical potential of InSe/Gr is 4.6 eV (with respect to vacuum), which is considerably higher than OER efficiency of –4.9 eV at pH = 13. Moreover, the InSe/Gr heterogeneous structure allows OH– aggregation on the anode surface, with a calculated adsorption energy of –0.74 eV (Fig. 13(j)). The photocurrent-voltage characteristics of the synthesized devices were measured and are summarized in Figs. 13(k) and 13(l). Under illumination conditions, the LSV curve shows an oxidation onset potential of about 420 mV for OH–. The measured photocurrent density J was found to increase as a function of the illumination time t, and this yielded a large saturation current density J max > 10 mA cm–2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE. Xie's group [ 181 ] covered porous graphene (pGr) monolayers with NiO x thin films modeling electrocatalyst-modified n-Si substrates for PEC OER. The process of synthesizing composites as photoanodes is depicted in Fig. 14(a) . The pGr cover layer was shown to form a porous structure by Raman spectrum (Fig. 14(b)). From the current potential (J-V) curve of Fig. 14(c), the number of impacts of Gr has a significant impact on the PEC OER performance under different impact conditions. As indicated in Fig. 14(d), the photocurrent onset potential of the n-Si/TiO2/NiO x /pGr photoanode vs. RHE was 1.13 ± 0.01 V, and the photocurrent density (J 1.23) at 1.23 VRHE was 8.08 ± 1.0 mA cm–2. As shown in Fig. 14(e), the photocurrent onset potential of the n-Si/TiO2/NiO x /pGr photoanode vs. RHE was 1.13 ± 0.01 V, and the photocurrent density (J 1.23) at 1.23 VRHE was 8.08 ± 1.0 mA cm–2. Fig. 14(f) indicates that resistance value of n-TiO2/NiO x /pGr decreases significantly, while the resistance value of n-Si/TiO2/NiO x /pGr increases significantly. Xie et al. [ 182 ] proposed the construction of a sandwich structure with transition metal oxides/SLG/transition metals as the core to modify n-Si based photoelectrode materials. The synthesis of n-type Si/TiO2/NiO x /SLG/Ni is shown in Fig. 4(g). The synthesized photoanode SEM images are indicated in Figs. 14(h)–(j). The current density-potential (J-V) curve in Fig. 14(k) demonstrates that n-Si/TiO2/NiO x /SLG/Ni has higher performance than n-Si/TiO2/NiO x /Ni without SLG. Meanwhile, the maximum ABPE value of n-Si/TiO2/NiO x /SLG/Ni at 1.14 VRHE is 1.0% (Fig. 14(l)), which is 3.5 times higher than that of n-Si/TiO2/NiO x /Ni without SLG. In conclusion, carbon-based catalysts have abundant electronic states and energy level structures, which are favorable for the separation and migration of photogenerated charges. Carbon-based catalysts also have high conductivity and stability, which can effectively transport photogenerated charges and reduce the loss of electron-hole complexes and have a wide application potential as photoelectrocatalytic materials. 2.6.6 MOF-based catalysts MOF-based materials, as a class of mature crystalline materials, have better structural tunability than traditional crystalline materials. The abundance of metal nodes as well as functional tunability enables MOFs to be precisely designed to meet the demands of PEC [ 183–186 ]. Pan et al. [ 187 ] coated NiFe MOFs on the surface of oxygen rich defect BiVO4 (Ov BiVO4) and constructed a core-shell structure of NiFe MOFs with caffeic acid bridging groups (Fig. 15(a) ). At 1.23 VRHE, the photocurrent density of Ov-BiVO4@NiFe-MOFs is 5.3 ± 0.15 mA cm–2, which is much higher than other photoanode materials (Fig. 15(b)). The APBE curve showed that the maximum of Ov-BiVO4@NiFe-MOFs reaches 1.62% at 0.7 V vs. RHE, which is about 8 times that of BiVO4 (Fig. 15(c)). Compared to RHE, the APBE curve indicates that Ov-BiVO4@NiFe-MOFs can reach up to 1.62% at 0.7 V, which is more than 8 times higher than BiVO4. At 450 nm, the order of IPCE values from smallest to largest is BiVO4 (20.5%) < Ov-BiVO4 (28.4%) < Ov-BiVO4@NiFe-MOFs (72.9%), which indicates that the loading of oxygen vacancies and NiFe-MOFs is an effective way to enhance the photoelectrocatalytic activity of the system (Fig. 15(d)). At the same time, the electrochemical impedance followed a similar order (Fig. 15(e)). Yang et al. [ 188 ] improved the photogenerated electron transport efficiency by compounding CoFe MOF material on the BiVO4 surface. Fig. 15(f) shows a novel nanomaterial prepared on a fluorine doped oxide (FTO) substrate modified with binary metal organic framework materials (MOFs). Fig. 15(g) illustrates the LSV curves of the synthesized composites. The results demonstrate that the current density of BVO@CoFe MOF(NA) is 2.10 mA cm–2 at 1.23 VRHE, whereas the pure BVO is only 0.65 mA cm–2. This indicates that CoFe MOFs have a good synergistic effect in improving the reaction rate of water. LSV observations in the dark further confirmed this conclusion (Fig. 15(h)). According to the results in Fig. 15(i), BVO/CoFe MOF(NA) showed the ABPEmax is 1.09% and higher than the other synthesized photoanodes at 0.79 VRHE, which suggested that CoFe MOF (NA) optimized the catalytic activity of the system better than CoFe MOF (5-ana). The highest IPCE value of BVO/CoFe MOF (NA) is 89% near 400 nm (Fig. 15(j)). Lee's group [ 189 ] prepared MIL(125)-NH2/TiO2 nanocomposites using a hydrothermal method and studied their PEC OER activity. Fig. 16(a) indicated the synthesis of TiO2 NRs photoanodes by hydrothermal method and the synthesized photoanodes. The MIL(125)-NH2/TiO2 NRs exhibit a significantly high PEC performance of 1.63 mA cm–2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE (Fig. 16(b)). Fig. 16(c) indicated the photocurrent density of pristine TiO2 NRs and MIL(125)-NH2/TiO2 NRs. The measured ampere photocurrent showed that the synthesized photoanode maintains a high stability within 50 h. The highest IPCE value of MIL(125)-NH2/TiO2 NR reaches 84.4% at λ = 340 nm, which is close to 2.5 times more than that of pure TiO2 NR (Fig. 16(d)). The EIS spectra indicate that the impedance value of MIL(125)-NH2/TiO2 NR is lower than that of TiO2 NR, which demonstrates that the MIL(125)-NH2 coating greatly contributes to the carrier transfer capability of the composite (Fig. 16(e)). Pan et al. [ 59 ] used a metal organic framework compound (cMOFs) with good conductivity to coat Ti:Fe2O3. Core-shell Ti:Fe2O3@CoFe-cMOFs photoanodes were prepared by a ligand-driven self-assembly process using CA as a ligand (Fig. 16(f)). The photocurrent density was further increased to 3.3 mA cm–2 at 1.23 VRHE after plating bimetallic CoFe-cMOFs on the Ti:Fe2O3 surface, which was higher than the other two photoanodes (Fig. 16(g)). The ABPEmax value of Ti:Fe2O3@CoFe-cMOFs reached 0.34% at 1.05 VRHE (Fig. 16(h)). Fig. 16(i) shows the IPCEs values at 1.23 VRHE at 400 nm in the order of Ti:Fe2O3@CoFe-cMOFs (63.5%) > Ti:Fe2O3@Co-cMOFs (52.4%) > Ti:Fe2O3 (36.3%) from largest to smallest. Fig. 16(j) indicates that the current density of Ti:Fe2O3 at 1.23 VRHE is 2.8 mA cm–2 in Na2SO3 solution and 1.2 mA cm–2 without Na2SO3 solution. In summary, MOF-based catalysts have highly tunable structures and compositions, which enable MOF materials to be optimally designed for different photoelectrocatalytic reactions and to improve catalytic efficiency. In addition, MOF materials are rich in functional groups, which can regulate the electron transport and reaction routes in catalysis. MOF materials can also be doped, or surface modified to adjust the energy band structure and photovoltaic properties and broaden the range of light adsorption. 3 Photoelectrocatalysis CO2 reduction reaction 3.1 Basic principles of PEC CO2 reduction reaction (PEC CO2RR) Conventional thermocatalytic CO2 reduction is conducted at high temperature (at least 500 °C) and high pressure (10 bar). The photocatalytic, electrocatalytic and PEC CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) process using solar or electrical energy and catalyst to catalyze the conversion of CO2 [ 68,190,191 ]. Using solar-powered catalysts, carbon dioxide can be reduced and processed to CO or other high-value products [ 33,192,193 ]. However, the reduction of CO2 is still technically challenging due to the high dissociation energy of C=O of about 750 kJ mol–1 [ 194 ]. In industrial production, the products of the PEC CO2 reduction reaction have different values products. Currently, the products of PEC CO2 reduction reactions include mainly C1-like products (CO, CH4, CH3OH, HCOOH) and C2 and C2+ like products (C2H4, C2H6, C3H6, C2H5OH, etc.) as illustrated in Table 2 [ 41,117,164,195,196 ]. Currently, research on PEC reduction of CO2 is progressing rapidly, but the theoretical system required to utilize solar and electro energy in catalytic reactions for conversion to chemical compounds is not yet fully mature. Based on its excellent application background and industrial value, a large amount of research work exists to explore in depth the products and reaction mechanisms produced by PEC reduction of CO2, where SHE is the normal hydrogen electrode [ 197–201 ]. For example, PEC generation of CH4 requires more electrons and more energy than the generation of CO, which means that the reaction process is more difficult [ 14,202–204 ]. For CO2RR, the photocatalytic and electrocatalytic reactions proceed in the same way, and the reaction energy barriers required for the different products are essentially similar. During the PEC CO2RR reaction, CO2 is the first to bind to the active sites on the catalyst surface, and then a series of reaction energy barriers are overcome, resulting in different products. It should be noted that the beam-decision step in PEC CO2RR is a key step in the reaction process, which can reveal the mechanism of the reaction process and provide a reference for improving the catalytic activity of the system. However, CO2 uptake at the active site is also a very critical step, and only if the CO2 uptake is effective, the products can achieve high selectivity in the subsequent reaction steps, which also promotes the improvement of reaction stability. The reduction of CO2 has also been an important means to achieve the dual-carbon goal in recent years, which has attracted worldwide attention. However, this technology has still not been industrialised on a large scale worldwide due to the disadvantages of uncertainty in selectivity and products, and poor stability. Therefore, overcoming the above drawbacks to achieve industrialisation is the future trend. 3.2 Catalyst design principles for PEC CO2RR As far as CO2RR is concerned, the assays and activity evaluation criteria used for photocatalysis are not the same as for electrocatalysis. Photocatalytic CO2RR mainly uses gas chromatography to detect the yields of different products and thus calculate the apparent quantum efficiency to compare the catalytic activity. On the other hand, electrocatalysis mainly calculates the target selectivity after detecting the yields of different products by gas chromatography, and a high selectivity implies a high catalytic activity. Whether catalysts are used for photocatalytic or electrocatalytic CO2RR, high CO2 adsorption is required to ensure higher productivity or selectivity of subsequent products [ 205,206 ]. For photocatalysis, the CO2RR process requires many photogenerated electrons to participate in the reaction and a high separation efficiency of photogenerated electron-hole pairs to be maintained. Therefore, catalysts for photocatalytic CO2RR are mainly semiconductors and need to have a high light absorption capacity and a high photogenerated electron-hole pair separation efficiency. Representative catalysts include TiO2, sulfide, and carbon nitride-based materials, etc. For the electrocatalytic CO2RR process, the catalysts need to have a high electrical conductivity to be able to maintain high selectivity at low potentials. Therefore, the catalysts commonly used for electrocatalytic CO2RR are mainly noble metal or transition metal clusters/oxides/sulfides. Representative metal elements include Ag, Cu, Au, Ni, Fe, Ga, etc. The PEC CO2RR reaction detection method and activity evaluation criteria are similar to those of electrocatalytic CO2RR. The difference is that in the PEC CO2RR process, additional solar energy is applied to overcome the energy potential barriers required for the conversion to different products, so as to improve the reaction efficiency. And the photogenerated electrons on the catalyst surface by light also have a synergistic promotion effect, which can maintain the high conductivity and selectivity of the system. In summary, for catalysts used in PEC CO2RR, catalysts with good catalytic activity should have the following characteristics: (1) excellent electrical conductivity, capable of high carrier transfer rate during the reaction process; (2) excellent photosensitivity, capable of absorbing energy over a wide spectral range and maintaining a high photogenerated electron yield and separation efficiency of electron-hole pairs; (3) high stability, can maintain high catalytic activity under long time reaction conditions. 3.3 Synthesis methods of catalysts for PEC OER Catalysts for PEC CO2RR are synthesised by a variety of methods, including electrodeposition, physical vapour deposition (PVD), sol-gel synthesis, hydrothermal synthesis, chemical vapour deposition (CVD) and solution-based techniques such as drop-casting or spin-coating. Composite catalysts combining multiple materials are also common and are usually synthesised by co-electrodeposition, co-sputtering or in situ growth methods. The method of catalyst synthesis has an impact on factors such as selectivity, stability and compatibility with photoelectrochemical systems for a given CO2 reduction product, and therefore simple and high-yield methods need to be selected to enable large-scale industrial production. 3.4 Configuration of PEC CO2RR Typically, the PEC reduction of CO2 is measured in a three-electrode configuration, and the three electrodes are commonly used to evaluate the reaction efficiency of the photocathode. The common reaction equipment is an H-type electrolyzer or a two-compartment electrolyzer, and the common reference electrodes are Ag/AgCl or Hg/HgO electrodes. To prevent mixing of the cathode and anode electrolytes, the double chamber electrolytic cell is usually separated by a proton exchange membrane (Nafion, etc.) to avoid reverse oxidation of the products on the anode (Fig. 17 ) [ 207 ]. 3.5 General parameters to evaluate the PEC CO2RR Commonly used measurements of PEC CO2RR are by LSV, timed current (i-t) or timed potential (v-t) under dark or light conditions. Key indicators of the reaction results are Faraday efficiency (FE) for different products, CV curves, i-t curves, photocurrent densities and parameters indicating sample stability, etc. The FE to the product was calculated by quantifying the ratio of electrons in the PEC reaction that contributes to the production of the product with the following Eq. (4) [ 75 ]: (4) FE (A) = αn(A)F/Q where the reaction product is set to be A, α is the number of electrons required to reduce CO2 to produce a molecule of A, n(A) is the molar amount of A, F is Faraday's constant, and Q is the total charge that passes through the circuit in the process of producing n(A) moles of A. In addition, the algorithms for value of STH, IPCE and APBE for the PEC CO2RR reaction were similar to those for the PEC OER reaction [ 75 ]. 3.6 Different catalysts for PEC CO2RR We classified the catalysts commonly used for PEC CO2RR into three categories: Cu-based, metal oxides/nitrides, and porphyrins catalysis and summarized them (Fig. 18 ). 3.6.1 Cu-based catalyst Cu-based catalysts are widely used for electrocatalytic and PEC CO2RR due to their good electrical conductivity, tunable band gap, and good adsorption of intermediates for the CO2RR reaction process [ 208 ]. In industrial production, the cost of Cu is also much lower than that of various precious metals (e.g. Au, Ag, Pt, Pd), therefore Cu has broad application prospects in the future [ 209 ]. Since Cu-based materials have been reported in many literatures with a wide range of research directions, they are reviewed here in a separate subsection [ 210–214 ]. Kempler et al. [ 90 ] prepared a silicon-based photocathode by electrochemical deposition of Cu on the vertical side walls of micrometer fibers with aspect ratio. The synthesized catalytic system for the reaction is shown in Fig. 19(a) . Fig. 19(b) illustrated a comparison of the J-E behavior of the illuminated planar n+p-Si/Cu and n+p-Si μW/Cu electrodes in the plating cell prior to and after transferring a charge of –1.00 C cm–2 in the direction of the copper deposition, respectively. The partial current density behavior Jx -E of copper deposited on n+p-Si μW in catalyzing the generation of CO, CH4, and C2H4 consistently shifted toward a more positive potential, with the magnitude of the shift varying depending on the different reduction products (Fig. 19(c)). The n+p-Si μW/Cu electrodes were more active toward H2 than the Cu foils (Fig. 19(d)). Roh and coworkers demonstrated stable aqueous PEC CO2R by attaching copper nanoparticles (CuNPs) to np-SiNW photocathodes (Figs. 19(e) and (f)) [ 215 ]. The PEC CO2RR performance of this CuNP/SiNW array was tested under simulated light conditions (Fig. 19(g)). Fig. 19(h) illustrates the selectivity of the CO2RR gas products under different catalyst mass usage conditions. Figs. 19(i) and (j) indicated the activity of CuNP/SiNW against C2H4. The main product of CO2RR, FE(C2H4), reached more than 20% at –0.45 V vs. RHE and 25 ± 6% at –0.55 V vs. RHE (Fig. 19(i)), which was the highest value for wet side illuminated PEC CO2RR. The Tafel slope for the conversion of CO2RR to C2H4 by the CuNP/SiNW system was 93 ± 14 mV dec–1 (Fig. 19(j)), suggested that the single electron transfer carbon-carbon coupling step is the decisive step in the reaction process. Toma's group [ 94 ] provided a protection scheme by revealing the changes in the cuprous oxide (Cu2O) photoelectrode under reaction conditions. Since APXPS showed the presence of Cu2+-OH (aq) at the interface in the presence of light, which may disrupt the charge transfer from Cu2O to the catalyst, as shown in Fig. 20(a) . The photocurrent density presented by Ag/Cu2O in aqueous solution at 0.4 V vs. RHE is lower than that of pure Cu2O (Fig. 20(b)). On the other hand, when used AcCN, which prevents the disproportionation of Cu2O and thus prevents the formation of Cu2+-OH (aq) species (Fig. 20(c)), the Ag catalyst increased the initial photocurrent density of Cu2O at –1.2 V vs. Fc/Fc by a factor of about 1.8 (Fig. 20(d)). In addition, the formation of Cu2+-OH (aq) species was effectively prevented when using AcCN (Fig. 20(c)), and the Ag catalyst resulted in a significant increase in the initial photocurrent density of Cu2O at –1.2 V vs. Fc/Fc (Fig. 20(d)). These phenomena suggest that preventing the formation of Cu2+-OH (aq) species at the interface can accelerate the charge transfer at the solid/liquid interface and effectively prevent Cu2O from undergoing chemical transformation. In addition, the synergistic effect of the Ag catalyst and the heterogeneous structure of ZS on the modification of Cu2O resulted in a reductive photocurrent for the Ag/Cu2O/ ZS/FTO reaction, with current density of –1.3 mA cm–2 (Fig. 20(e)). The system selectively and sustainably produced C2H4 (FE ~60%) and H2 (FE ~40%) (Fig. 20(f)). Xiong's group [ 216 ] developed a facile method to coat the Cu2O cathode surface with a MOF material. Fig. 20(g) illustrates the photocathode contains a columnar Cu3(BTC)2 MOF structure on the surface of a Cu2O film. As indicated in Fig. 20(h), the CO generation rate of Cu3(BTC)2/Cu2O at applied potentials between –1.77 and –1.97 V vs. Fc/Fc+ was as high as ~95%. The Cu3(BTC)2/Cu2O/ITO photocathode achieved STC efficiency of 0.83% (Fig. 20(i)), which is comparable to the benchmark photocathode (0.87%). In summary, the special position and active center of the copper surface make it highly CO2 selective, which has good application prospects in the field of CO2 conversion and provides potential catalysts for the treatment of CO2 pollution. 3.6.2 Metal oxides/nitrides Metal oxides and nitrides, which combine high conductivity and high photosensitivity, are also widely used in PEC CO2RR. Shan and co-workers report the coupling of molecular p-n junction assemblies with single integrated semiconductor p-n junction-n-type GaN (n-GaN) nanowires on n+-p-p+ silicon (Si | n-GaN) for PEC CO2RR [ 217 ]. The structures of the synthesized composites are indicated in Figs. 21(a) and (c) and SEM images are shown in Fig. 21(b). The relative energy levels of the whole system are shown in Fig. 21(d). Photocathodes Si|n-GaN| -NPhN- Ru(CP)2+ 2-RuCt subjected to solar irradiation (AM 1.5G) in CO2-saturated NaHCO3 produced significant photocurrents vs. RHE (–0.40 to –0.80 V vs. RHE) over the range of the applied bias from 0 to –0.4 V (Fig. 21(e)). The photocathode continued to produce formic acid under solar irradiation (AM 1.5G), and the Faraday efficiency increased from 35% to 64%, indicating a relatively stable photocurrent (Fig. 21(f)). Coating a layer of silver catalyst on the surface of GaN nanowires using PEC deposition method in AgNO3 containing hydrothermal solution (Fig. 21(g)) [ 218 ]. The silver catalyst was transformed into AgX by repeated anodic oxidation and reduction in a KX electrolyte under sunlight irradiation (Fig. 21(h)). When the photocathode is under light conditions, the photogenerated carriers in the wafer spontaneously migrate to the surface of GaN NW and AgX (Fig. 21(i)). The AgBr/GaN/Si indicated excellent stability even when gaseous products were strongly generated at the strong potential of –1.0 VRHE over the time interval of 9 to 12 h (Fig. 21(j)). The photocathode consisting of GaN nanowires coated with cu on a silicon wafer by Dong et al. [ 219 ] can effectively reduce CO2 gas mixtures containing H2S to HCOOH (Fig. 22(a) ). The reductive photocurrent density of –0.9 mA cm–2 was measured at –1.0 VRHE with onset potential of –0.4 VRHE (Fig. 22(b)). The Cu-assisted catalyst deposited on a silicon substrate (Cu/Si) started to produce HCOOH at –0.4 VRHE and showed a maximum FEHCOOH of 20.7% at –1.0 VRHE (Fig. 22(c)). The maximum jHCOOH of Cu/GaN/Si was 7.07 mA cm–2 (Fig. 22(d)). The reaction showed a slight decrease in FEHCOOH and j HCOOH at –1.0 VRHE compared to the first reaction, probably due to the reduction of CuS to Cu (Fig. 22(e)). Pan and coworkers [ 220 ] used non-precious metal NiOOH/α-Fe2O3 and Bi/GaN/Si silicon wafers as photo-anode and photocathode, respectively (Fig. 22(f)). Arrays of GaN nanowires modified with biomaterials (called Bi/GaN/Si) were used on single crystal silicon wafers for PEC CO2RR (Fig. 22(g)). The SEM image (Fig. 22(h)) indicates that GaN is aligned perpendicularly to the Si substrate. The performance of Bi/GaN/Si was greater improved than GaN/Si, with an onset potential of 0.1 V. The photocurrent density produced at –0.8 V was as high as 22.1 mA cm–2 (Fig. 22(i)). The addition of Bi co-catalysts greatly improved the formate selectivity with a maximum selectivity of 85.2% (Fig. 22(j)). Mi's group found that in the CO2RR catalytic system, a novel active center, namely the metal/oxide surface, is introduced on its surface to automatically activate CO2 and stabilize it during CO2 reduction, thereby improving CO conversion efficiency [ 221 ]. The schematic design of Pt-TiO2/GaN/n-p Si was illustrated in Fig. 23(a) , and the SEM cross-section is shown in Fig. 23(b). Fig. 23(c) shows a comparison of the LSV curves. The photocurrent density reaches ∼120 mA cm–2 at –0.33 V when loaded with both Pt and TiO2 compared to bare Pt. Fig. 23(d) illustrates the FE of CO and H2 for the synthesised material with selected potentials between +0.47 V and +0.07 V. At the applied potential of +0.47 V, the FE of CO is as high as 78%. By adjusting the potential from +0.47 V to +0.07 V, the CO/H2 ratio can be adjusted over a wide range, contributing to the PEC CO2RR performance. Zhou and colleagues [ 14 ] report a unique GaN:Sn nanostructure integrated on planar silicon for PEC CO2RR formic acid production (Figs. 23(e) and 23(f)). Fig. 23(g) illustrates the bandgap diagrams for different materials, where both GaN and Si are n-type doped. As depicted in Fig. 23(h), the photocurrent density in pure silicon is very low due to high photogenerated electron and hole complexation in the potential range of +0.3 to –0.8 V. The photocurrent density in pure silicon is very low due to the high photogenerated electron and hole complexation. By adding GaN NWs, both the onset potential and current density are ideally improved. Among the three co-catalysts, only Sn NPs were able to effectively promote the formation of formic acid (Fig. 23(i)) with a catalytic efficiency of 76.9%, whereas the main product of the reaction of Co- and Ni-based co-catalysts was H2 accompanied by traces of CO (FE < 1%). Leung et al. [ 97 ] reported a precious metal-free molecular catalyst photocathode for CO2 reduction in water. The photohybrid system consists of a mesoporous titanium dioxide (meso TiO2) layer-modified p-silicon (Si) photocathode and an adsorbed cobalt catalyst (Fig. 24(a) ). With increasing H2O content, the number of cycles increased from 13 to 108 after 8 h of CPPE (Fig. 24(b)), and the selectivity increased from from 12% (9:1 MeCN:H2O) to 53% (7:3 MeCN:H2O). The photocurrent was very stable with a total Faraday efficiency of 77% (FECO = 48%) and a TONCO2 of 159 were achieved (Figs. 24(b)–(d)). In the optimal electrolyte solution (6:4 MeCN: H2O), LSV indicated that the cotpypp-functionalized photoelectrode displayed approximately twice the photocurrent and occurred ~120 mv earlier (Fig. 24(e)). The active site for CO2 reduction catalysis was finally identified as originating from CotpyP by multiple sets of controlled experiments in 6:4 MeCN:H2O solution (Fig. 24(f)). Li et al. [ 222 ] utilized the gold catalytic layer grown at grain boundaries and the amorphous silicon absorber modified on the surface of TiO2 to obtain a larger photogenerated voltage, thereby achieving higher photoelectric conversion efficiency. By adjusting the GB density of the Au layer, it is possible to obtain syngas with different carbon-to-hydrogen ratios with a wide range of PECs from –0.1 VRHE to plus 0.4 VRHE (Fig. 24(g)). Both the ST-4Au and ST-7Au samples produced high photocurrents of 6 mA cm–2 at –0.2 VRHE, with an early onset potential around 0.5 VRHE (Fig. 24(h)). For the a-Si/TiO2 electrode, the Faraday efficiency (FE) of H2 is close to 100% at all potentials and no CO is generated (Fig. 24(i)). In addition, by varying the applied voltage to the ST-4Au sample, which resulted in a high concentration of CO, the CO/H2 ratio ranged from 1:2 to 1:3.1 (Fig. 24(j)). On the ST-7Au electrode, a wide potential range of –0.1 to 0.3 VRHE produces a syngas with a CO/H2 ratio of 1: 1 (Fig. 24(k)). In conclusion, metal oxides/nitrides have been widely recognized for their high catalytic activity, high product selectivity and stability during PEC CO2RR reactions. In the future, metal oxides/nitrides can be used for industrial conversion of CO2 to produce high-value products. 3.6.3 Porphyrin-based catalysts Porphyrin molecules are widely used in the design and synthesis of many types of photovoltaic conversion materials because of their broad spectral adsorption range, highly conjugated rigid planes, flexible and easily tunable structures and functions, and high chemical stability. Porphyrin molecules have a flat π-conjugated structure, which allows them to absorb light in the visible and near-infrared regions. This strong light adsorption ability makes porphyrin materials have a wide range of applications in fields such as photoelectrocatalysis and photosensitive materials [ 223,224 ]. Yang's research team [ 225 ] uses copper to manufacture formic acid products and replaces the central magnesium of its chlorophyll with Au, Cu, or Co (Fig. 25(a) ). Fig. 25(b) showed the TEM images of the HNTM after immobilization of the corresponding metal atoms on the HNTM (HNTM-M-SA) (Fig. 25(c)). Fig. 25(d) illustrated the Fourier transform (FT) k3-weighted EXAFS spectra of HNTM-Au-SA at the Au L3 side. Compared with the reference samples, no significant Au-Au (2.1 and 2.7 Å), Au–H (0.9 Å) and Au–Cl (1.8 Å) coordination peaks were detected. They proposed a schematic model for HNTM-Au-SA in the inset of Fig. 25(e). A single gold atom is coordinated to four N atoms and anchored to the center of the porphyrin unit, ultimately forming the active site for the catalytic reaction. In addition, HNTM-M-SA consistently maintained the highest FEmax under visible light irradiation (Fig. 25(f)). As illustrated in Fig. 25(g), the activation of CO2 on both sides of the porphyrin planes may have a synergistic effect on HNTM-Au-SA. Wang and coworkers [ 226 ] designed and synthesized Cu@porphyrin-COFs nanorods materials using a solvothermal method, and then electrodeposited Cu nanowires onto free radical porphyrin-COFs on carbon fibers. Electrochemical deposition of Cu on porphyrin based COFs can effectively accelerate electron transfer speed and capture protons, thereby providing convenience for C–C coupling (Fig. 25(h)). Methanol (CH3OH) and ethane-1,1-diol(CH3CH(OH)2) were detected at an external voltage of –0.8 V (Fig. 25(i)). When using Cu@[OH]-H2P-COF/CF photocathodes in PEC batteries, the total formation rate of hydrocarbons (Fig. 25(j)) was significantly increased by nearly 3 times compared to [OH]-H2P-COF/CF photocathodes (Fig. 25(k)). The CO2 conversion efficiency of the Cu@[OH]-H2P-COF|KHCO3|Pt cell was about 5 times that of the EC plus PC at –1.0 V (Fig. 25(l)). Wei et al. [ 227 ] modified the internal structure of cobalt tetraphenylporphyrin (CoTPP) catalyst by annealing to improve the catalytic activity. Fig. 26(a) illustrates the synthesis of different photocathodes for PEC CO2RR by loading graphene on a silicon substrate and subsequently immobilizing CoTPP molecules. The LSV results in Fig. 26(b) showed that the photocurrent density rises rapidly above the starting potential. The partial current density increases significantly with the rise of negative potential, and the selectivity to CO. The highest selectivity for CO is achieved at –0.1 V (vs. RHE), which is 82.8%. The lowest PEC performance for Si/rGO/Co further suggests that the conducting graphene has a significant impact on the PEC performance of the promoted system (Fig. 26(c)). At voltage of –0.1 V (vs. RHE), with 75% selectivity for CO, the stable photocurrent was approximately 2.2 mA cm–2 and reacted stably for 16 h (Fig. 26(d)). The PEC performance and stability of Si/rGO-Co exceeded that of the PEC CO2RR catalyst (Fig. 26(e)). Huang's group [ 164 ] anchored the Ru(bpy)3Cl2 branched chain as a powerful photosensitive material to a covalent organic skeleton based on Co-porphyrin via a coordination reaction (Fig. 26(f)). The synthesized catalysts showed FECO up to 96.7% at –0.7 V (vs. RHE) and current density up to 16.27 mA cm–2 at –1.1 V (vs. RHE). LSV images showed that the current densities of Co-Bpy-COF-Ru1/2 and Co-Bpy-COF were higher than those measured in the corresponding electrolytes saturated with N2 (Fig. 26(g)), verifying the higher activity of CO2RR than that of the HER-responsive HER. Under light conditions, the onset potential of Co-Bpy-COF-Ru1/2 was more favorably oriented towards positive potentials vs. RHE, and the current density was increasingly high, up to 30 mA cm–2 at –1.2 V (Fig. 26(h)). The FECO of Co-Bpy-COF-Ru1/2 exceeded 80% in the potential range of –0.5 to –0.9 V, reaching FEmax of 96.7% at –0.7 V (Fig. 26(i)). Meanwhile, the TOFs of Co-Bpy-COF-Ru1/2 were also significantly increased under light conditions, reaching a maximum value of 933 h–1 at –1.1 V, which was much higher than that under dark conditions (681 h–1 at –1.1 V, Fig. 26(j)). In conclusion, porphyrin-based catalysts possess strong light adsorption ability and rich electronic state structure, making them widely used in photoelectrocatalysis. The structural tunability and coordination ability make the porphyrin materials have diverse functions and properties, which can be regulated to meet different needs, and have greater research value and broad research prospects. 4 Advanced modification strategies for catalysts in PEC OER and CO2RR. For catalysts employed in photoelectrochemical oxygen evolution reactions (PEC OER) and carbon dioxide reduction reactions (CO2RR), leveraging advanced modification strategies is crucial for enhancing their efficiency and selectivity. These strategies encompass various techniques such as doping [ 228 ], manufacturing defect [ 229 ], formation of single or diatomic atoms, creation of heterojunctions, microenvironmental modulation, and others. Collectively, these advanced methodologies hold significant promise for designing and developing highly efficient catalysts tailored for PEC OER and CO2RR, thereby playing a vital role in advancing sustainable energy conversion technologies. 4.1 Doping Doping is the introduction of small amounts of foreign atoms into a catalyst material to alter its physico-chemical properties [ 230–232 ]. The technique can adjust the reactivity, selectivity, stability, or other characteristics of the catalyst to achieve higher reaction efficiencies. Doping can be accomplished by a variety of methods such as impregnation, ion exchange or chemical vapour phase deposition. The usual doping methods are substitution doping and interstitial doping. Substitution doping is to replace the position of the target atom by entering the heteroatom into the lattice, while gap doping is to change the lattice parameter of the material by entering the heteroatom into the gap between the lattice, both of which are to change the electronic structure of the catalyst by changing the internal lattice structure of the material to change the electronic structure of the catalyst, the ligand environment, and other properties [ 233–238 ]. Bao and his colleagues [ 239 ] have prepared Si-doped ZnAl-LDH with photoresponsive properties. The synthesised catalysts enhanced the light absorption and photoresponsive effects. Fig. 27(a) indicates the schematic diagram of the synthesis process, where Si-doped LDH nanosheets were finally obtained by chemical exfoliation method of layering after the addition of SiCl4 on the surface of Zn-Al LDH.
