The morphology of Si-ZnAl-LDH is a spherical-like structure and its surface consists of thin nanosheets (Fig. 27(b)). Atomic force microscopy (AFM) images demonstrated similar edge heights for ZnAl-LDH nanosheets (Fig. 27(c)), while the edge heights of Si-ZnAl-LDH nanosheets (Fig. 27(d)) were not uniform. The LSV curves, EIS results, and C dl results all indicate the best PEC OER performance of the Si-doped LDH. It is since the doping of Si changes the carrier transfer efficiency of the system and effectively accelerates the separation of photogenerated electrons and holes, thus enhancing the catalytic activity of the system (Figs. 27(e)–(h)). This work provides a new idea and a feasible strategy for modifying the photoelectric properties of LDH materials. Similarly, Dong et al. [ 240 ] also enhanced the catalytic activity by doping Mn on the FeBTC/NIF surface to change the energy level structure of the catalyst, which enhanced the light absorption capacity and increased the carrier transfer rate. The catalytic activity enhancement was more obvious under light. This work also demonstrates that doping can effectively enhance the catalytic activity of the system by changing the properties of the catalyst such as the structure or electronic coordination environment. Fig. 27(i) demonstrates the synthesis process of the catalyst, and the Mn-FeBTC/NIF with a lamellar structure was obtained by the electrodeposition method. whereas the reaction process on the surface of the NIF when a constant voltage was applied during the deposition process is shown in Fig. 27(j). Similarly, the LSV curves, EIS results and C dl results indicate that the Mn-doped Mn(II)-FeBTC/NIF has the best OER performance. Whereas the OER performance of all samples was enhanced under light, Mn(II)-FeBTC/NIF still had the best PEC OER performance (Figs. 27(k)–(n)). It is demonstrated that doping can change the electron transfer efficiency of the whole system, accelerate the adsorption of intermediates, and enhance the catalytic activity. In conclusion, doping, as a common modification method, has been applied in numerous catalyst systems. Doping is widely used for its diverse methods and obvious effect on the enhancement of catalytic activity. 4.2 Manufacturing defect Manufacturing defects are defects or irregularities introduced into the lattice of a material during its synthesis. These defects can include vacancies, interstices, dislocations, and grain boundaries. Crystal defects can alter the forbidden band width, electronic structure, coordination environment and other properties of the catalyst, which is beneficial to the catalytic activity [ 241–246 ]. Peng's group [ 247 ] fabricated a gradient vacancy concentration from the surface of BiVO4 surface after a simple solvent-thermal treatment method via N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), which not only improved the carrier transport but also established a favourable energy band structure and optimised the catalytic activity. Figs. 28 (a1)–(a6) shows AC-STEM images of BVO and B(VO)1–δ obtained by DMF treatment with different vacancy concentrations, and it is evident that the atomic arrangement of the initial conformation changed significantly after DMF post-treatment. The reconstitution process suggests that post-processing can lead to the removal or rearrangement of specific atoms, and depending on the treatment, a gradient-like change in vacancy concentration is formed. These results suggest that DMF post-treatment can effectively lead to the formation of vacancies within the lattice. The DMF post-treatment process leads to easier dissolution of surface VO4 3– and formation of VO4 vacancies with gradient features in the B(VO)1–δ film as Bi and V gradually decrease, as shown in Fig. 28(b). The gradient energy band structure of the B(VO)1–δ film was finally formed (Fig. 28(c)). The results of LSV, ABPE and IPCE curves all indicate that the catalytic activity of the B(VO)1–δ photoanode is stronger than that of the BVO, demonstrating that the vacancy gradient promotes charge separation and increases the photocurrent, enhancing the catalytic activity of the system (Figs. 28(d)–(f)). Li's group [ 71 ] also found the effect of vacancy concentration on photoelectrocatalytic activity. By modulating the concentration of oxygen vacancies in PbCrO4, they found that the oxygen vacancies could introduce different electronic energy levels, thus generating higher charge separation photovoltaic voltage, accelerating carrier transport and enhancing the catalytic activity. Li's group also found the effect of vacancy concentration on photoelectrocatalytic activity. By modulating the concentration of oxygen vacancies in PbCrO4, they found that the oxygen vacancies could introduce different electronic energy levels, thus generating higher charge separation photovoltaic voltage, accelerating carrier transport, and enhancing the catalytic activity. They characterised the energetic differences between O-rich and O-poor PbCrO4 by surface photovoltage microscopy (SPVM). The O-poor PbCrO4 exhibited a larger SPV than the O-rich PbCrO4 in different wavelength ranges (Figs. 28(g) and 28(h)). It is due to O-poor PbCrO4 has a slightly lower WFlight due to a higher concentration of oxygen vacancies and a higher WFdark due to a deeper surface capture state, and thus a higher SPV intensity, compared to O-rich PbCrO4. Fig. 28(i) indicates that the open-circuit voltage (OCP) of O-rich and O-poor PbCrO4 is lower in light conditions than in dark conditions, while O-poor PbCrO4 has a higher photovoltage than O-rich PbCrO4. The higher photovoltage of poor O PbCrO4 (203 mV) than rich O PbCrO4 (170 mV) is further demonstrated by the statistical photovoltage in Fig. 28(j). As illustrated in Fig. 28(k), under AM1.5G illumination, while the oxygen-depleted PbCrO4 photoanode produces a photocurrent density of 3.43 mA cm–2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE, which is about 2.5 times higher than that of the oxygen-enriched PbCrO4 photoanode. The increase in the photocurrent density indicates that the oxygen vacancies in oxygen-poor PbCrO4 produce deeper energy level populations, which is favourable to the photovoltage enhancement. In addition, the photocurrent densities of PbCrO4 photoanodes prepared under different annealing conditions ranging from oxygen-rich (100% O2) to oxygen-poor (0% O2) were gradually enhanced, which proved that the photocurrent densities were related to the concentration of oxygen vacancies. The similar trend of statistical photocurrent density and the corresponding J-V curves further confirmed the positive correlation between O-poor annealing and photocurrent density (Fig. 28(l)). Overall, crystal defects play a significant role in catalysis by enhancing surface reactivity, modifying surface chemistry, facilitating mass transport, and influencing electronic properties, ultimately leading to improved catalytic activity. 4.3 Single or diatomic atoms Single-atom catalysts are at the forefront and hotspot of catalytic science in recent years and have attracted much attention because of their maximum atom utilization efficiency and excellent performance. When the size of nanocrystals is reduced to clusters of atoms, single atoms, their energy level structure, and electronic structure undergoes a fundamental change. This unique structural property suggests that single-atom catalysts have a superior. It is due to this unique structural feature that the single-atom catalysts often show different activity, selectivity, and stability from the traditional nanocatalysts. On top of the single-atom research, the dual-atom research also came into being. By synthesizing two different single atoms, it is possible to achieve superior activity to that of single atom catalysts. Diatomic catalysts have also attracted the attention of researchers and have achieved greater research results in recent years. Single and diatomic catalysts can be used in the PEC process to precisely increase the atom utilisation, modify the electronic structure and increase the number of active sites, thus optimising activity and stability [ 248–256 ]. Bi's team [ 257 ] demonstrated that single atoms can increase the carrier transport rate and thus catalytic activity by synthesizing Co single atom-modified α-Fe2O3 photoanodes. Fig. 29(a) indicates typical atomic resolution high angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) image, which clearly shows that the Co atoms are dispersed on the C3N4 surface. Fig. 29(b) shows the Co k edge X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectrum of Co-C3N4. There is a distinct Fourier transform (FT) peak at 1.49 Å, which points to the Co–N bond with a coordination number of four. The LSV curves, ABPE curves, IPCE curves and EIS results show that the photoanodic performance of the loaded single atoms is significantly stronger than that of α-Fe2O3 (Figs. 29(c)–(f)). These results clearly show that photogenerated holes on Fe2O3 can be efficiently transferred to the C3N4 surface and subsequently to the monatomic Co active site during the PEC OER process. It is demonstrated that the Co single atom accelerates the carrier transfer and thus promotes the OER performance. Zhang et al. [ 258 ] proposed a multi-purpose coupling strategy by designing single-atom Ni-N4 sites covered on the BiVO4 surface, simultaneous coordination of atomically dispersed Ni-N4 sites with axial oxygen atoms (Ni-N4-O) (Fig. 29(g)). The results showed that Ni-N4 promotes the separation of photogenerated carriers, which improves the PEC activity of the system. The LSV curves, ABPE curves, and IPCE curves indicate that the photoanodic catalytic activity of the loaded monoatomic and co-catalysts is significantly stronger than that of pure BiVO4 (Figs. 29(h)–(j)). Among them, the ABPE value of FeOOH/Ni-N4-O/BiVO4 is even 2.66%, which is 5.43 times higher than that of pure BiVO4, higher than the previously reported work (Fig. 29(k)). These results indicate that the construction of single-atom Ni-N4-O groups promotes carrier transfer and lowers the reaction energy barrier, thus improving the catalytic activity. Wang et al. [ 259 ] developed a novel N'nn'-chelate ligand (N3)-coupled cobalt porphyrin (CoPor-N3) polymer, in which the synergistic interaction between the internal electron-rich N3 ligand and the Co-N4 monatomic site resulted in more electrons being gained in the Co center, the facilitates carrier transfer and improves the reduction of CO2 by the catalyst. Fig. 30(a) indicates schematic top and side view structures of cobalt porphyrin (CoPor-N3) polymers coupled with N3 chelating ligands. The TEM images showed that the morphology of the synthesised catalysts was flaky (Fig. 30(b)), Aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC-HAADF-STEM) images (Fig. 30(c)) showed the distribution of many Co atoms. The EDS mapping images show the elements of the synthesised materials were all displayed (Figs. 30(d1)–(d4)). FECO amply demonstrated that the CO selectivity of CoPor-N3 under light was significantly higher than that under dark conditions at the same potential, suggesting that the single atoms effectively enhanced carrier transfer and inhibited the complexation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs, facilitated CO2 reduction, and suppressed the effect of the competing reaction HER (Figs. 30(e) and (f)). In addition, they constructed a PEC cell by using CoPor-N3/CC as a photocathode and NiCo-LDH/CuPc/BiVO4/ FTO as a photoanode, as shown in Fig. 30(g). The FECO was compared, and the results showed that the dual-photoelectrode cell had a higher selectivity of CO than the single-photoelectrode cell at the same potential (Fig. 30(h)). It is demonstrated that the dual photoanode can optimise the light absorption capacity of the system, leading to more photogenerated electrons transferring to the monoatomic active site, thus promoting the PEC CO2RR performance. Chen and coworkers [ 260 ] precisely synthesised the diatomic Ir1Pd1 on In2O3 by photo-induced domain deposition. The synergistic effect of this diatomic structure significantly promotes CO2 conversion and methanol product selectivity with desirable stability. Fig. 30(i) illustrates the schematic of the synthesis process, after co-precipitation and then photodeposition the catalyst containing diatoms was finally obtained. High-magnification HAADF-STEM images showed that most of the active sites were mostly two neighbouring atoms (Fig. 30(j)). Line contours (Fig. 30(k)) were used to identify the atom types, and the measured distance between Pd-Ir atoms was about 0.25 nm, which is close to the length of the metal-metal bond in Ir or Pd nanoparticles, in combination with the distribution function and atomic number analyses, confirming the presence of Pd and Ir diatomic structures in the synthesised catalysts. Fig. 30(l) shows that in the PEC CO2RR process, a conversion of CO2 of 10.5% and a methanol selectivity of 97% were achieved, and that this selectivity and conversion reached a level that could be industrialized. It is demonstrated that single atoms can improve the separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs and the adsorption of CO2, thus promoting the selectivity and stability of PEC CO2RR. When the metal loading was further increased, the STY value decreased significantly (Fig. 30(m)). This phenomenon is attributed to the formation of metal nanoparticles and the decrease in the content of loaded diatoms, where the higher the metal content is the lower the diatom content, leading to the decrease in conversion and selectivity. In conclusion, both single and dual atom catalysts can substantially increase the atom utilisation in the catalysts, increase the number of active sites, and increase the photogenerated electron transfer rate, thus optimising the catalytic activity of the system. The industrialisation of single and dual atom catalyst has broad prospect and research value in the future, especially when the synthesis method and cost are reduced, the single and diatomic catalysts are expected to achieve a blowout development in the future. 4.4 Heterojunctions Heterojunction is an interfacial region formed when two different materials encounter each other. Whether it is a conductor/semiconductor, a material of different dimensions, or other heterogeneous interfaces formed between different types of materials, they can be called heterojunctions. Heterojunctions can effectively enhance the carrier transfer rate, reduce electrical resistance, lower the adsorption energy of intermediates during catalytic reactions, separate photogenerated electron-hole pairs, etc. This series of favourable effects will improve the catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability of the system. We believe that if we imagine the carriers in a catalytic reaction as a car, the heterojunction is equivalent to a section of “highway”, which will greatly accelerate the transfer of carriers and thus enhance the catalytic activity of the reaction at the macroscopic level. Currently, the effect of heterojunction on the system in the catalytic reaction has attracted wide attention, and has a broad research prospect in the future, which is one of the feasible ways to achieve industrialization [ 237,241,261–264 ]. Xie et al. [ 265 ] synthesised NiFeO x /BVO/BiVO4 photoanodes with heterostructures by indicating in BiVO4 by electroplating and photodeposition methods. The experimental results show that the photocurrent density of NiFeO x /BVO/BiVO4 is significantly higher than that of pure BVO, which proves that the heterostructure can enhance the catalytic activity of the system effectively. Fig. 31(a) illustrates the synthesis process, where NiFeO x /BVO/BiVO4 photoanodes were finally synthesised by electroplating and photodeposition. The successful synthesis of BVO/BiVO4 is indicated by the lattice fringes in Fig. 31(b). The TEM-EDX images also clearly show the elemental composition of the NiFeO x /BVO/BiVO4 samples, indicating that NiFeO x was successfully deposited on the BVO/BiVO4 surface (Fig. 31(c)). The results of LSV curves, ABPE curves and IPCE curves show that the catalytic performance of the samples containing heterojunctions is higher than the activity of pure BiVO4. It means that the heterojunction can enhance the carrier transfer rate of the system, which has a greater effect on the catalytic activity of the system (Figs. 31(d)–(f)). Shang et al. [ 266 ] composed a photocathode by binding graphene to p-type silicon using an organic linker, protected by the addition of a TiO2 film, and subsequently anchoring cobalt phthalocyanine molecules to graphene oxide. The synthesised catalysts have ideal PEC CO2RR performance with peak CO selectivity of 86% and peak MeOH selectivity of 23%. This work presents a strategy for interfacing molecular catalysts with p-type semiconductors and suggests new ideas for the study of PEC CO2RR catalysts. Fig. 31(g) shows a schematic of the synthesis flow of the catalysts, where the GO/CoPc catalysts were assembled by non-covalent π–π stacking and then the CoPc molecules were assembled onto graphene oxide flakes by sonication in DMF solution. Under PEC conditions, the CO selectivity of STA-GO/CoPc was significantly higher than that of CFP-GO/CoPc at lower applied voltage, indicating that the heterojunction significantly improved the catalytic activity of the system at lower applied voltage. At higher applied voltages, CFP-GO/CoPc reached 23% peak selectivity for methanol under dark conditions. The peak selectivity of STA-GO/CoPc for methanol reached 6% under light conditions, although its onset potential was lower than that of CFP-GO/CoPc. However, it is possible that the reduced Co loading or the planar structure of the Si substrate does not efficiently capture photogenerated electrons at high potentials, resulting in a lower selectivity of STA-GO/CoPc for methanol than CFP-GO. In conclusion, this research work is the first successful integration of molecular catalysts on silicon used for PEC CO2 reduction to methanol provides feasible ideas and prospective research perspectives for molecular catalysts (Figs. 31(h) and (i)). In conclusion, heterojunction can increase the active sites and specific surface area, optimise the energy band structure, accelerate the carrier transport, and reduce the adsorption energy of intermediates on the active sites, thus enhancing the PEC activity of the system. Efficient and highly selective catalysts can be designed by researchers for a wide range of photoelectrocatalytic applications as a common modification method. 4.5 Microenvironmental modulation In catalytic reactions, the microenvironment is the local conditions surrounding the catalyst and reactants in the reaction system. It includes influences factor such as temperature, pressure, solvent composition, pH, reactants, use of surfactants, and reaction atmosphere. The kinetics, thermodynamics, stability, and selectivity of catalytic reactions can be effectively regulated by adjusting these influences. Specifically, regulating the microenvironment has the following benefits for catalytic reactions. Firstly, the selectivity is improved, which facilitates the formation of desired products while minimizing the generation of by-products from competing reactions. Second, reaction activity and selectivity are enhanced by promoting efficient mass transfer and facilitating favorable reactant-catalyst interactions. Third, the stability of the PEC catalyst was effectively promoted by extending the lifetime of the photogenerated carriers. In addition, microenvironmental conditioning permits precise control of the reaction pathway, making it possible to synthesize specific molecules with desired properties. Overall, optimizing the microenvironment in catalytic reactions can improve the efficiency, sustainability, and economic viability of chemical processes [ 267–272 ]. Jin's group [ 273 ] used a covalent triazine skeleton containing dithiophene (CTF-BTh) to modulate the microenvironment at the interface between Gd-doped hematite and cobalt silicate (Co-Sil) co-catalysts for efficient photoelectrocatalytic water oxidation. As shown in Fig. 32(a) , the reaction environment favorable to PEC CO2RR was created by modulating the microenvironment, which enhanced the carrier transfer rate and improved the product selectivity and stability. After the addition of Co-Sil co-catalyst and CTF-BTh, the inter-interfacial microenvironment was successfully regulated, which effectively accelerated the charge transfer rate and greatly inhibited the recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs (Figs. 32(b) and 32(c)). The LSV curves, chronoamperometry curves, ABPE curves and IPCE curves all showed that the catalytic activity of the photoanode was greatly improved by the addition of Co-Sil co-catalyst and CTF-BTh. It is since the addition of CTF-BTh passivates the surface and its abundant coordination bonds provide channels for charge flow, thus enhancing the oxidation state of Co. Meanwhile, the conjugated system of CTF-BTh is easy for electron delocalization and effectively inhibits the interfacial electron-hole complex. In addition, the modulation of the interfacial microenvironment can reduce the charge transfer resistance and increase the surface photovoltage. The synergistic effect of these modifications greatly improved the charge separation efficiency, charge transfer efficiency and catalytic activity of the system (Fig. 32(d)–(g)). Shang et al. [ 274 ] achieved improved CO2 reduction performance by designing the semiconductor/catalyst interface and modulating the electrode microenvironment for PEC, which is important for optimising the cascade reaction of CO2 reduction to methanol. They synthesized carbon nanotube/amine-substituted CoPc catalysts (CNT/CoPc-NH2) by preparing the surface of p-type silica carriers into micropillar arrays, which improved the light absorption capacity and catalytic activity. SMA structures with a column diameter of nanopillars were prepared by photolithography and dry etching and coated with a thin CF x layer using octafluorocyclobutane (C4F8) plasma (Fig. 32(h)). At an applied potential of –0.7 V, the methanol FE of the SMA-CF x -CNT/CoPc-NH2 photocathode was 21%, the CO FE was 37%, and the total photocurrent was 16.6 mA cm–2 (Fig. 32(i)). The system was tested for stability at a constant current of 15 mA cm–2 (Fig. 32(j)). The catalyst could still maintain high selectivity and stability within 50 h. When the reaction time was greater than 50 h, the stability of the catalyst gradually decreased with increasing time. The SMA-CF x -CNT/CoPc-NH2 photoelectrode optimised the overpotential due to the ideal photovoltage compared to the most efficient catalysts available (Fig. 32(k)). Overall, optimization of the microenvironment in catalytic reactions can improve the reaction efficiency, stability, and selectivity, and has broad application prospects. 5 Reaction step analysis of PEC OER and CO2RR based on theoretical analysis and in-situ characterization The main theoretical approaches to analyzing PEC reaction mechanisms include density functional theory (DFT) calculations, COMSOL simulations and machine learning. DFT calculations involve solving the quantum mechanical equations that control the behavior of electrons within a material, providing insights into the electronic structure, energetics, and reaction pathways of PEC systems. COMSOL Multiphysics is a powerful finite element analysis, solver, and simulation package for a variety of physics and engineering applications. Computational algorithms are used to simulate the behavior of PEC systems, enabling the prediction of material properties, reaction kinetics and reactions. Machine learning methods use algorithms to analyse large datasets of experimental and theoretical PEC data, extract patterns and correlations to predict reaction mechanisms, determine optimal reaction conditions, and design efficient PEC catalysts. These analytical methods provide complementary insights into the complex processes behind PEC reactions, facilitating the rational design and optimization of photoelectrode and PEC systems for renewable energy conversion and environmental applications. 5.1 Reaction step analysis of PEC OER and CO2RR based on DFT calculation DFT calculations can aid in identifying adsorption sites and configurations on the catalyst surface, revealing the interaction mechanism between the catalyst and reactants [ 60,275,276 ]. Calculation of reaction energy barriers and free energies on various catalyst surfaces can assess the catalytic activity and stability of catalysts, providing guidance for designing and optimizing efficient PEC OER catalysts. The OER process involves four basic reaction steps, which include different intermediate products (*OH, *O and *OOH, * denoting the active site of the catalyst) [ 124,125,277–280 ]. Song et al. [ 140 ] performed relevant theoretical calculation models based on different BiVO4-based photoanode. The results showed that the energy barrier of MoO x /MQD/BiVO4 is lower after the simultaneous introduction of MQD and MoO x on the BiVO4 surface (Fig. 33(a) ). The energy barrier for the conversion of MoO x /MQD/BiVO4 from *OH to *O can be plummeted to 0.63 eV at standard potential. The minimum free energy barriers of MoO x /MQD/BiVO4 indicate that simultaneous loading of MQD and MoO x can improve the PEC OER performance of the system (Figs. 33(b)–(d)) [ 139 ]. They also did DFT calculation analysis in another work, as shown in the constructed model (Fig. 33(e)). Theoretical calculations indicate that Co is the main active site for the PEC OER reaction, and the introduction of NiO between BiVO4 and Co-agzif-62 can induce a rapid charge transfer to Co-Ag Zif 62 for the PEC OER reaction (Figs. 33(f)–(h)). Chen's group [ 158 ] investigated the effect of surface sulfur vacancies on the PEC OER process and discussed the reaction mechanism utilizing DFT calculations. The maximum Gibbs free energy difference for pure CdIn2S4 (Fig. 34(a) , ΔG 3 = 2.418 V, η OER = 1.123 V) appears during the OOH* formation from O*, demonstrating that the adsorption of OOH* on CdIn2S4 is the reaction energy-determining step in the PEC OER process. Furthermore, although the potential determination process of Vs-CdIn2S4 remains unchanged, the Gibbs free energy decreases to 2.064 eV, resulting in η OER has significantly decreased. This phenomenon suggests that surface sulphur vacancies can reduce the formation energy of OOH* and thus the overpotential of the PEC OER (Fig. 34(b)). Fig. 34(c) indicates that the Fermi level and bandgap of Vs-CdIn2S4 under the bias voltage condition of 1.23 V do not change very much, further elucidating that the photon wells generated by the sulfur vacancies can enhance the PEC OER performance. To further elucidate the effect of trap states on the photogenerated electron transfer process in the PEC OER process, the sulphury vacancy-induced photogenerated electron jump from the mixed highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) state to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) state has been studied. As illustrated in Fig. 34(d), the charge densities of the mixed HOMO states do not change much, while the charge densities of the mixed LUMO states show a very significant increase in the sulfur vacancies near the In and Cd atoms. This phenomenon indicates that more charge densities within the Fermi energy level are generated in the LUMO state, which is beneficial to enhance the catalytic activity of the material. Ismail et al. [ 141 ] calculated the thermodynamic free energy diagram of the PEC OER. The side-view structures of *OH, *O and *OOH absorbed on the surface of SAs Pt: Fe2O3 are shown in Fig. 34(e). The calculated data indicate the existence of two OER paths (first OER path: Pt-OH → PtOOH → PtOOH): Pt-OH → PtOFe → PtOOH → O2; and the second OER path: Pt-OH → PtO → PtOOH → O2 on the SAs Pt: Pt: Fe2O3 surface). In conclusion, the analysis of the PEC OER process using DFT calculations not only efficiently analyzes the active site, but also analyzes the reaction-determining step based on the change of ΔG, which is beneficial for a deeper understanding of PEC OER. The analysis of photoelectrocatalytic oxygen-analysis reactions (PEC OER) using DFT calculations has the advantages of atomic-level resolution, adsorption and reaction free energy calculations, electronic structure analysis, prediction of photoadsorption properties, and applicability to complex systems. These advantages can provide an in-depth understanding of the photoelectrocatalytic reaction mechanism and catalytic material properties and provide theoretical guidance for optimizing photoelectrocatalytic systems and designing efficient photoelectrocatalytic catalyst. Reaction step analysis is an important process to study CO2RR, and the effect of catalysts on CO2RR and the reaction mechanism can be explored in depth through the study of different intermediates and related ΔG [ 63,281–284 ]. Li et al. [ 285 ] synthesized S vacancy-containing CuIn5S8 materials with Cu-In double sites in order to achieve very high photocatalytic activity for CO2 reduction for CH4 production. Briefly, Cu and In atoms can act as dual active sites in VS-CuIn5S8 materials to form COOH* intermediates more efficiently (Figs. 35(a), (b) ). This phenomenon contributes to lowering the reaction energy barrier of VS-CuIn5S8 to improve catalytic activity. Yang et al. [ 225 ] investigated the PEC CO2RR mechanism of metal single-atom-porphyrin structures by using DFT calculations on them. Research has found that in the dark state, external electrons can only reach LUMO, so a high overpotential is necessary to generate a HOMO-LUMO energy gap (Fig. 35(c)). Moreover, the energy required for T1 state is obtained from the adsorption of light, without the need for electricity (Fig. 35(d)). The T1 state has an energy of 1.7 eV higher than the S0 state, resulting in a decrease in overpotential of approximately 130 mV (Fig. 35(e)). Figs. 35(f) and (g) display the optimized structures of pure Pt(111) and Ti3O6H6/Pt(111) surfaces for CO2 adsorption, respectively. In addition, differential charge density (DCD) was detected, as indicated in Fig. 35(h) [ 221 ]. The results indicated that many electrons were transferred from the interface to the CO2 molecules to form activated *CO2-anions, which ultimately enhanced the CO2 reduction activity. Fig. 29(i) indicated the Gibbs free energies obtained by DFT calculations for PEC CO2RR reduction on Pt(111) and Ti3O6H6/Pt(111). On pure Pt(111), the value of the free energy change (ΔG) for the CO2 activation to form the *COOH intermediate is 5.08 eV, which is the decisive step for the whole reaction process. Mi's group [ 218 ] analyzed the PEC CO2RR by DFT calculation. The calculated energy barrier for CO2RR conversion to CO for AgCl and AgBr is lower than that for Ag (Fig. 36(a) ) due to their different reaction energy barriers in the critical step of converting CO2 to *COOH intermediates. Meanwhile, the projected density of states (PDOS) of the surface silver species was calculated (Fig. 36(b)). The results indicate that the lower energy of the 4d state of the Ag element in AgBr and AgCl implies that these Ag+ bind strongly to the *COOH intermediates and form *COOH with a lower energy barrier, which can effectively facilitate the PEC CO2RR reaction. Wei et al. [ 227 ] conducted a theoretical study on the adsorption free energy of intermediate products in the CO2RR reaction using density functional theory, confirming that external light can effectively reduce the energy level of RDS during CO2 reduction. Reduction of CO2 adsorption form CO is mainly adsorption of CO2 and formation of *COOH and *CO through carrier transfer to form CO at the Co center site (Fig. 36(c)). Fig. 36(d) demonstrates that the generation of *COOH is the RDS of Co-Bpy-COF-Ru1/2. The energy barrier for formation of *COOH on the surface of Co-Bpy-COF-Ru1/2 decreases dramatically from 1.16 to 0.25 eV when under light conditions. This phenomenon was also demonstrated by the experimental results, i.e., FECO, j CO and TOF were higher under light conditions than under dark conditions, further revealing that visible light illumination conditions are an important influencing factor in enhancing the catalytic activity. Zhou et al. [ 14 ] have theoretically explained the synergistic effect of GaN NWs and Sn NPs by DFT calculations, thus promoting the catalytic activity of the system. The DCD is illustrated in Fig. 36(e). Charge density rearrangement occurs near the interfacial region, a phenomenon that suggests strong electronic coupling between the Sn NPs and GaN NW materials. The results showed that the presence of ionic Ga–O bonds and covalent Sn–N bonds between Sn NPs and GaN NWs altered the electronic structure at the interface to a certain extent, which may play a key role in the PEC CO2RR. In order to conduct a deeper investigation of the synergistic interaction between GaN NWs and Sn NPs, the CO2 adsorption around the Sn13O26/GaN(101‾0) interface was explored. As shown in Fig. 36(f), the presence of covalent and ionic bonds at the Sn13O26/GaN(101‾0) interface leads to the reduction of CO2 to *CO and *O. The total energy diagram for the reduction of CO2 to HCOOH and the corresponding fully relaxed conformation is shown in Fig. 36(g). During the reaction, *COOH is reduced to HCOOH in four steps by the active hydrogen produced by water splitting. In conclusion, DFT calculations can reveal the reaction mechanism of PEC CO2RR, including adsorption state, insertion reaction, and addition reaction. By calculating the energies and reaction paths of the intermediate states, the steps of electron transfer and chemical bond formation can be clarified, providing theoretical guidance for optimizing the PEC CO2RR reaction. Meanwhile, the product selectivity of PEC CO2RR can also be predicted, and the free energy of generation of each product can be calculated based on the various adsorption configurations on the catalyst surface, to predict the ratio of the main products and by-products. This helps to optimize the catalyst and reaction conditions to improve the selectivity of CO2RR. This can provide an in-depth understanding of the PEC CO2RR reaction mechanism and catalytic material properties and provide theoretical guidance for optimizing photoelectrocatalytic systems and designing efficient PEC CO2RR catalysts. 5.2 Reaction step analysis of PEC OER based on COMSOL simulations With COMSOL, researchers can simulate real-world systems, optimize their design and predict the performance of their products under different reaction conditions. It is widely used in the automotive, aerospace, electronics, energy, catalysis, and biomedical industries. It has a broad application prospect and high research value [ 22 ]. Wu et al. [ 286 ] enhanced the photoelectrocatalytic activity of the system by designing amorphous B-doped TiO2 and used COMSOL simulation to analyse the potential changes induced by potentiodynamic field polarization in the internal structure of different samples. As shown in Fig. 37(a) , the TiO2 crystal structure was assumed to be neatly arranged. Each 20 × 20 × 20 nm model is in the same state in the electric field. Figs. 37(b) and (c) both show the variation of lattice parameters in the disordered state and after B doping. The dipole orientation of all three structures is disordered and distributed in the direction of the electric field before and after polarization, respectively, and the electric field inside the material is strong after polarization. However, after removing the electric field, completely different dipole distributions are observed in the three models. Overall, i.e., a higher sustained residual polarisation-induced electric field leads to band bending and generates a stronger potential difference, which results in a faster separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs and improved catalytic activit. These simulation results further validate that amorphous/crystalline heterojunction and oxygen vacancies can effectively modify the structure and electrical conductivity of TiO2, providing a theoretical basis and a feasible strategy for the study of TiO2 modification. Based on COMSOL simulations, Zhang's group [ 287 ] proposes to construct three-dimensional photonic crystal structures with feature sizes to synchronously modulate the light absorption and carrier collection properties of photoelectrodes to enhance the photoelectrode performance. Figs. 37(d)–(i) show the 2D optical models of different films. According to the formula describing the spatial distribution of light intensity, a larger electric field intensity indicates increased light transmission and reduced light absorption. Based on the COMSOL simulation results, they concluded that io-CBO 200 (feature size 200 nm) will exhibit stronger PEC performance for CO2 reduction, while Planar-CBO has the worst performance. It was also shown by testing the PEC CO2RR performance that io-CBO 200 exhibits a higher stability of about 2.67 times that of the thin film photocathode (Fig. 37(j)). This work demonstrates the enhancement of PEC CO2RR performance by fast carrier transfer from a theoretical point of view, which provides a feasible idea and strategy for the modification of the catalyst. In conclusion, com simulation explores the tuning of reaction conditions by realistically simulating the reaction environment of the system, thus providing theoretical ideas and feasible strategies for designing efficient catalysts. 5.3 Reaction step analysis of PEC OER based on machine learning Machine learning (ML) is a branch of artificial intelligence (AI) that enables computers to “self-learn” from training data and improve over time without explicit programming. Machine learning algorithms can detect patterns in data and learn from them to make predictive behaviors. Machine learning techniques can be used to filter out the best of hundreds or thousands of conditions that can be used to predict the optimal catalyst composition and structure, electrode morphology, and reaction conditions to improve efficiency and selectivity. The combination of machine learning and photoelectrocatalysis holds great promise for advancing renewable energy technologies and solving environmental challenges through the analysis of large datasets including material properties, reaction kinetics and experimental conditions [ 288–294 ]. Gao et al. [ 295 ] summarise the challenges and current advances in ML in materials science, categorising and highlighting design strategies. Although cross-cutting research in materials science related to machine learning shows strengths, there are still challenges that need to be properly addressed and deeply understood. To this end, the authors summarise strategies for applying ML to materials science: increasing the amount of data, ML processing of feature studies (enhancing feature analysis optimisation, exploring relationships between features, classifying features into different categories, identifying material feature attributes), development of specialised algorithms for materials science, optimising and evaluating learning models, and development of open-source materials packages and ML frameworks. Screening and prediction by machine learning can bring reference and guidance to catalyst development (Fig. 38(a) ). Wang and co-workers [ 296 ] report the application of ML to study key criteria for dopant selection to improve PEC performance in photoelectrodes. They used hematite Fe2O3 as a prototypical semiconductor candidate to train ML models using data obtained from 17 dopants, each containing five unique dopant concentrations. In the ML study, 10 intrinsic features (e.g. atomic number, ionic radius, chemical valence, etc.) and one processing feature (dopant concentration) were used as descriptors and six different algorithms were applied, including baseline linear regression (LR), random forests (RF), gradient boosting (GB), support vector regression (SVR), k-nearest-neighbour regression (KNN) and neural networks (NN). This work shows that machine learning (ML) is expected to provide predictable insights into dopant selection for high-performance PEC systems, which can reveal the correlation between many characteristics of the dopant and the performance of PECs with doped photoelectrodes (Fig. 38(b)). Overall, machine learning has broad application prospects and research value in the future, and can provide researchers with greater reference significance in screening and prediction, and the combination with photoelectrocatalysis holds great promise for advancing renewable energy technologies and solving environmental challenges. 5.4 In-situ characterization of PEC OER and PEC CO2RR Commonly used in-situ characterization methods include in-situ infrared, in-situ Raman, in-situ XPS, in-situ synchrotron radiation, etc. In-situ characterisation is dynamic, real-time and intuitive. It enables the study of catalytic reactions in a transient state, and the results are irreplaceable for the selection and design of catalysts. In addition, in-situ characterisation allows real-time observation of the process, structure and morphology of chemical reactions, and the acquisition of information such as reaction intermediates, which helps researchers to analyse the reaction mechanism, and thus promotes the further development of chemistry and materials science. Venugopal et al. [ 297 ] chose BiVO4 as a model photoanode to study the metal oxide/electrolyte interface using operational photoelectrochemical attenuated total reflection Fourier transform infrared spectrum (PEC-ATR-FTIR). Fig. 39(a) shows the device they developed to measure the PEC-ATR-FTIR spectra. In Fig. 39(b), the PEC-ATR-FTIR spectra are positively tilted with time during photocharging. It is due to the Drude absorption of free electrons into the infrared, which increases at low wavelengths. Therefore, the spectral slope increases with time and the concentration of photogenerated electrons in BiVO4 gradually increases during photocharging. Fig. 39(c) compares the spectra of BiVO4 after photocharging in borate buffered electrolyte and ultrapure water. The results show that the concentration of hydroxyl/water species at or near the surface increases with the course of photocharging. When an anodic potential is applied under light conditions, dissolution of Bi and V is observed, and the difference in the rate of dissolution of V/Bi under light alters the surface elemental content ratio and leads to the formation of a Bi enriched surface on the pristine bulk BiVO4. In addition, the spectrum results also indicate that the decrease in vanadium concentration is an interfacial process and occurs only at the BiVO4/water interface. Landaeta and co-workers [ 298 ] synthesised plasma dendritic electrodes of silver and cuprous oxide (Ag/Cu2O) and observed the conversion of CO2 to the value-added compound acetate in the PEC CO2RR process by in situ Raman spectrum and explored the changes in the surface of the catalyst and the reaction mechanism. Fig. 39(d) shows the trend of the spectra recorded from a CO2 saturated solution under LED illumination over time, with peaks occurring that are thought to correspond to functional groups or chemical bonds corresponding to those found in the literature. It is noteworthy that the peak corresponding to acetate changes significantly, which proves that the concentration of acetic acid gradually increases as the reaction proceeds. When potential of –0.4 V was applied, the bands of the Cu2O surface species disappeared, indicating rapid surface activation with the adsorption of CO2 molecules. Analysis of the intensity of the CO band during the reaction using surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) spectroscopy (Fig. 39(e)) shows that the CO concentration on the surface of the catalyst increases rapidly at the beginning of the reaction, and then decreases and stabilises when it reaches the maximum value. The deconvolution of the *CO peak (Fig. 39(f)) indicates that at least two different interactions are detected at the electrode. With a gradual change in the applied potential, the intensity of the *CO band shifts to high frequencies and the low-frequency component disappears. The result demonstrates the important influence of Cu on the selectivity during the reaction. SERS detection of CO on Ag/Cu2O/pentanethiol electrodes showed that the addition of pentanethiol could favour the formation of acetate (Fig. 39(g)). In addition, formate and acetate signals were still detected even at low potentials, demonstrating that the PEC CO2RR activity at low potentials remained unaffected. It could be that photogenerated electrons reached the Cu2O surface to promote PEC CO2RR. Liu et al. [ 299 ] proposed the preparation of sub-nanometer alumina layers (~0.45 nm) by atomic layer deposition to enhance the turn-on voltage of nanowire-structured zinc ferrites. Through a series of in situ characterization means, the team explored the formation and distribution of surface states in zinc ferrites and their effect on the properties. Fig. 40(a) shows the operando UV-visible spectra measured in the absence of light in the range 350–750 nm, centered around 455 nm. It can be surmised that the high-valent iron cation (4-valent) intermediate state formed during the aqueous oxidation reaction may be this surface state. Ding's group [ 300 ] modified BiVO4 photoanodes by Fe doping and caffeic acid/nickel iron oxide (CA/NiFe) modification and detected the active species in the PEC reaction using in situ infrared spectrum. The results show that the characteristic absorption peaks attributed to the O2 –* and OOH* actives are significantly enhanced as the reaction proceeds. It indicates that under light conditions, water molecules adsorbed on the catalyst surface first pass through the photogenerated holes and then dissociate at the Fe and Ni active sites to produce OOH, which is subsequently transformed into active species (O2 – and ·O2 –) and finally into O2 (Fig. 40(b)). Liu et al. [ 301 ] investigated proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) for water oxidation on five photoanodes and Ni1–x Fe x OOH-modified silicon (Si) by combining rate law analysis of H2O molecules with H/D kinetic isotope effect (KIE) and in situ spectroscopic studies. The PEC OER mechanism and limiting factors were explored, which in turn elucidated the reaction kinetics. For the α-Fe2O3 photoanode, it is shown that the ·OH adsorbed on the α-Fe2O3 surface is consumed during water oxidation (Fig. 40(c)). The result confirms the involvement of H2O molecules as direct reactants in the water oxidation on Ni1–x Fe x OOH/α-Fe2O3 photoanodes and verifies the mechanistic transition from sequential proton-electron transfer (SPET) to concerted proton-electron transfer (CPET) after Ni1–x Fe x OOH modification. The same ATR-FTIR measurements were carried out in CH3CN/D2O mixed electrolyte, which is consistent with the above mechanism. The signal peaks in Fig. 40(d) indicate that the asymmetric and symmetric telescopic vibrations of α-Fe2O3 and OD adsorbed on the Ni1–x Fe x OOH/α-Fe2O3 surface are related to the asymmetric and symmetric telescopic vibrations, which confirms that the hydrogen-bonded H2O molecules are consumed on the Ni1–x Fe x OOH/α-Fe2O3 surface. The infrared results show that pristine α-Fe2O3 can oxidise OH adsorbed by dissociatively adsorbed H2O, while Ni1–x Fe x OOH/α-Fe2O3 can oxidise hydrogen-bonded H2O molecules and adsorbed OH. This work demonstrates that Ni1–x Fe x OOH can modulate PCET, altering the PEC OER reaction mechanism at the surface, and elucidates an effective strategy to regulate PCET kinetics of water oxidation at semiconductor surfaces. 6 Comparison between PEC technology and other catalytic technologies Electrocatalysis, photocatalysis and photoelectrocatalysis have been described in the above section, however, other catalytic technologies are also relevant and used in industrial production. These include thermal catalysis and enzyme catalysis. The combination of photocatalysis and thermocatalysis has led to the development of photothermal catalysis, which has many similarities with enzymatic catalysis. In the next section, we will introduce thermal catalysis, enzyme catalysis and photothermal catalysis and compare them with PEC technology. 6.1 Thermocatalysis Thermal catalysed reaction is a kind of chemical reaction carried out at high temperatures, which uses a catalyst to lower the energy threshold of the reaction, thus increasing the rate and efficiency of the reaction. This reaction principle is widely used in the chemical industry, environmental protection, and energy fields, and has brought many conveniences and benefits to human production and life [ 302–307 ]. Thermal catalysts can change the reaction route of a reaction, allowing the rate and efficiency of the reaction to be increased. The principles of thermo-catalysed reactions are based on the theories of chemical kinetics and physical chemistry and include a variety of mechanisms such as surface catalysis, redox, and acid-base catalysis. Thermal catalysis technology can use catalysts to convert fuels such as natural gas and coal gas into liquid fuels or chemicals, increasing energy efficiency and reducing pollution emissions. In addition, thermocatalytic reactions can be used in the preparation of hydrogen, the synthesis of liquid fuels and the preparation of biomass fuels. These applications can improve energy sustainability and reduce energy costs, providing an effective solution to human energy needs. In conclusion, the principle and application of thermocatalytic reaction are very extensive, and it brings much convenience and benefits to human production and life. In the future, with the development of science and technology and the increasing demand of human beings for environment and resources, thermal catalysed reaction will have broader application prospects and more far-reaching significance. 6.2 Photothermal catalysis Photothermal catalysis is a new technology integrating photocatalysis and thermal catalysis proposed by scholars in recent years. Photothermal catalytic reaction can not only improve the efficiency of catalytic reaction, but also transform the low-density solar energy into high-density chemical energy [ 308–317 ]. Photothermal catalysis can be divided into three main categories: (1) thermally assisted photocatalytic reaction, mainly driven by light, the catalyst itself does not have thermal catalytic activity, and thermal energy helps to further reduce the apparent active energy of photocatalysis; (2) light-assisted thermocatalytic reaction, heat energy is the main driving force of the whole reaction, light radiation mainly plays the role of raising the local temperature, and photochemical effects may exist simultaneously; (3) photothermal coupled catalysis, where the heat released by the photothermal effect can promote the reaction process, and the photochemical effect enhances the apparent activity, and the synergistic effect of thermochemistry and photochemistry is not just a simple addition of the two reactions, but exceeds the sum of the photocatalytic and thermocatalytic activities. Zhang's group [ 318 ] prepared a series of novel CoFe-based catalysts (denoted as CoFe-x by H2 reduction of CoFeAl-LDH nanosheets at different temperatures and explored the photothermally catalysed CO2 hydrogenation performance under simulated solar excitation. Under the light condition, the synthesized catalysts showed a maximum CO2 conversion of 78.6%, a selectivity of 35.26% for C2+ and a good stability (Fig. 41(a) ). Yao et al. [ 319 ] combined carbon-based solid acids with interfacial solar heating to propose a new interfacial photothermal catalytic system with non-homogeneous catalysts to improve the conversion efficiency of the esterification reaction (Fig. 41(b)). Due to the heating effect of the interface of the SGA in the system in the presence of light, the resulting ethyl acetate will evaporate rapidly, which leads to a fast reaction, thus increasing the yield of EA. Lou and colleagues [ 320 ] converted aged spent lithium cobalt oxide (LCO) cells into a photothermal catalyst, and the catalyst could facilitate the recycling of waste polyester. Fig. 41(c) summaries the photothermal catalyst for upgrading waste LCO into waste polyester for up-cycling. With this technology, profit margins can be generated by converting waste or pollutants into high-value chemical products, and the profit margins generated can be doubled when the catalyst life is extended. With this technology, profit margins can be generated by converting waste or pollutants into high-value chemical products, and the profit margins generated can be doubled when the catalyst life is extended, demonstrating the promise and value of industrialising photothermal catalytic technology. With this technology, profit margins can be generated by converting waste or pollutants into high-value chemical products, and the profit margins generated can be doubled when the catalyst life is extended, demonstrating the promise and value of industrialising photothermal catalytic technology. Zhang's group [ 321 ] also successfully obtained a series of novel Co-containing photothermal catalysts by H2 reduction of ZnCoAl-LDH at different temperatures. The product selectivity of CO hydrogenation under photoluminescence can be tuned according to the reduction temperature (Fig. 41(d)), among which the Co-450 catalyst achieves the most excellent FTO performance, with C2+ products selectivity of 41.9%. 6.3 Enzyme-catalysed Enzymes are proteins that act as catalysts, initiating and accelerating these chemical reactions and ensuring that the results of these chemical reactions are consistent. Enzymatic reactions (also known as enzyme-catalysed) are chemical reactions catalysed by a special class of proteins called enzymes. Since the rate of non-catalytic reactions is particularly slow, catalysis of biochemical reactions in cells is extremely important. The mechanism of enzyme catalysis is very similar in principle to other types of chemical catalysis. Enzymes reduce the energy requirements to reach the highest energy transition state by providing alternative reaction routes and by stabilising intermediates [ 322–331 ]. Enzymes live in a very benign environment in living organisms, essentially in aqueous solution, with an approximate neutral pH, a low concentration of salts, and a temperature close to room temperature. These advantages offered by enzyme catalysis are what make it promising for future industrialisation. Enzyme-catalysed reaction has very high transferability, high production efficiency, can reduce the consumption of chemical reagents and organic solvents, and produce less waste and by-products, will not cause greater pollution to the environment, these enzyme-catalysed has the advantages of the future industrialisation of its prospects [ 332 ]. In recent years, biocatalysts have achieved rapid development and simplified design and synthesis routes as theoretical calculations and characterisation techniques have been investigated to meet the growing demand in catalysis. Current research strategies for biocatalysts include screening for natural diversity, directed design, redesign mechanisms, and calculations from a theoretical perspective (Fig. 42 ) [ 332 ]. Enzyme catalyst is also a kind of biocatalyst, these strategies can also be applied to the study of enzyme catalysts. Currently, enzyme catalysts are potentially valuable as mild, environmentally friendly catalysts with unique catalytic mechanisms and reaction conditions for large-scale industrialisation. 6.4 Photoenzymatic catalysis Photo-enzymatic catalysis is a combination of enzyme catalysis and photocatalysis, which integrates the diverse reactivity of visible light chemistry and the high selectivity of enzymes, solving to a certain extent the problems faced by visible light catalysis and enzyme catalysis respectively, and at the same time realising the highly efficient, sustainable, and green manufacturing of high value-added compounds through the integration of their respective advantages [ 333–349 ]. On the one hand, based on the active chemical intermediates generated by visible light catalysis under mild conditions, photo-enzyme catalysis is not only capable of utilising light regeneration cofactors to exert the natural activity of enzymes, but also triggering the unnatural reaction activity of enzymes to obtain new functions. On the other hand, by taking advantage of the high selectivity and directional evolvability of enzyme catalysis, photo-enzymatic catalysis is able to modulate light-triggered reactive intermediates, thus providing new solutions to the stereochemical control challenges in the field of photochemistry. Although photo-enzymatic catalysis is just emerging, the strategy has already shown great application prospects in synthetic sciences. At present, photo-enzymatic catalysis has been successfully used to catalyse important biochemical reactions such as carbon-carbon, carbon-nitrogen, carbon-oxygen, carbon-halogen bonding, etc., and has demonstrated its unique advantages in terms of catalytic activity, reaction selectivity, and substrate spectrum expansion. Sun et al. [ 350 ] established the enantiomeric decarboxylative alkylation of amino acids with α-heterocyclic olefins by a synergistic combination of ‘ene'-reductase (EREDs) and photoredox catalysis (Fig. 43(a) ). The scheme is extremely innovative with excellent chemical and enantioselectivity as well as a wide range of substrates. Overall, this synergistic approach provides an innovative mechanism for radical generation and extends the types of reactions that can be achieved asymmetrically using non-natural enzyme catalysis. As a family of enzymes with many members, pyridoxal 5′-phosphate (PLP)-dependent enzymes have diverse structures and functions and can catalyse C–C and C-heteroatom bonding reactions at the α, β, and γ positions of amino acids through a carbonyl-catalytic mechanism (Fig. 43(b)). Using a synergistic catalytic strategy of photoredox catalysis and pyridoxal 5'-phosphate (PLP) biocatalysis, Yang's group [ 351 ] developed a pyridoxal radical biocatalytic method to prepare valuable unnatural amino acids and construct unnatural amino acids with two or three stereocentres without the need for a protecting group (Figs. 43(c) and (d)). The experimental results proved the feasibility of their strategy, and it is worth mentioning that L-amino acids and D-amino acids can also be obtained by the photo-enzymatic catalysis technique. This synergistic catalytic strategy provides a new idea for the study of asymmetric catalytic radical intermediates. Yang's group [ 352 ] designed fatty acid photodecarboxylases to catalyse the formation of the C–C bond of unnatural photoredox radicals using strong oxidative excited state flavonoid quinone cofactors. Through genome mining, rational design and directed evolution, a series of radical photocyclases were developed to facilitate the cyclisation of decarboxylated radicals with excellent chemoselectivity, enantioselectivity and stereoselectivity (Fig. 43(e)). Chen and coworkers [ 353 ] integrated the three-linear state energy transfer, a typical photocatalytic mode, into proteins, and inserted functionally modified non-natural amino acids into proteins through genetic reprogramming to create artificial photoenzymes containing three-linear state photosensitisers, which successfully catalysed the intramolecular [ 2+2 ] photoexcited cycloaddition reaction of indole derivatives (Fig. 43(f)). This study extends the energy transfer reaction activity of artificial trilinear-state photoenzymes in supramolecular protein cavities and opens a valuable integrative approach to enantioselective photochemical synthesis that achieves goals that could not be achieved by the synthetic or biological domains alone. In conclusion, photocatalysis can be combined with other catalytic technologies to produce new technologies, such as photoelectrocatalysis, photothermal catalysis, and photo-enzymatic catalysis. This cross-disciplinary idea can be used in all aspects of catalysis, thus providing feasible strategies and future research prospects for solving the problems of high efficiency, environmental protection, and cost of catalysts. 7 Conclusions and perspectives Currently, electrocatalytic technology is well established for industrial and commercial applications [ 354,355 ], while the industrial application of photocatalytic technology still needs a lot of exploration to enhance the reaction efficiency. However, electrocatalytic technology requires a large amount of electrical energy to ensure the continuity of the reaction. The use of large quantities of electricity will inevitably involve the use of fuel or nuclear power generation to supply sufficient capacity, which not only increases production and technology costs, but also carries the risk of polluting the environment. The use of wind or water energy may change this situation, however, not all environments are suitable for generating electricity from these two energy sources. Whereas light energy is a primary energy source, the use of solar energy for photocatalytic reactions greatly reduces production costs and the risk of environmental pollution [ 356 ]. However, photocatalysis cannot be used on a large scale due to the difficulty of its industrialisation. Firstly, the evaluation standards of photocatalytic performance are not the same, such as the amount of catalyst, the concentration of reaction solution, the intensity of light, the range of wavelengths and so on, which is also the difficulty in evaluating the performance of photocatalysis. Secondly, the efficiency of photocatalysis is not satisfactory, mainly because the compound rate of photogenerated electron-hole pairs is too fast, which affects the catalytic activity and hinders its industrialisation. Finally, the large-scale use of photocatalysts requires high light absorption efficiency and, most importantly, high absorption efficiency of visible light to achieve industrial production. In summary, photocatalytic technology still needs a lot of research work before it can meet the challenge of industrialisation. In view of this, the use of photoelectrocatalytic technology to combine the technical characteristics of photocatalysis and electrocatalysis and improve the shortcomings of both will become the trend of catalytic technology in the future [ 357,358 ]. PEC technology with the advantages of environmental protection, energy saving and controllable material cost, the reaction process can be optimized, and large-scale industrial application is expected to be realized in the future. On the one hand, PEC technology can solve the shortcomings of photogenerated electron-hole pair compounding rate and long reaction time in photocatalysis; on the other hand, PEC technology can reduce the overpotential required for the reaction under high current density in electrocatalytic process, which saves electricity and improves the efficiency of the reaction at the same time. Meanwhile, the core advantage of PEC technology is that the reaction process is mild and has little pollution to the environment. The catalyst itself does not cause secondary pollution to the environment, which makes this technology has a broad application prospect in the future. Moreover, the economic benefits of PEC technology have been demonstrated in the literature, which makes the industrialization of PEC technology feasible in the future. This review focuses on the fact that PEC technology can be applied to CO2 reduction and water oxidation reactions, and on this basis the industrialisation of PEC technology can be promoted (Tables 3 and 4 ). For example, high-value organic products are prepared by PEC CO2RR. Through PEC oxidation technology or inverse reactions, other related reactions can be derived, such as urea oxidation (UOR), glycol oxidation (GOR) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) can be applied to industrial production, and ORR reactions can be applied to produce zinc-air batteries. All these applications have industrialisation value and prospects, creating economic benefits as well as achieving green environmental protection. In the future, PEC technology will be oriented towards intelligence, innovation, and environmental friendliness to meet the challenges of future industrialisation, thus achieving a “win-win” situation in terms of income generation and environmental protection (Fig. 44 ). We hope that this review will help others to understand the principles better and faster, commonly used materials, application prospects and development trends of PEC technology. Based on this review, we would like to provide reference and ideas for researchers to enrich their knowledge and viewpoints on PEC technology. In recent years, with the development of PEC technology, both experimental and application phases have achieved stage-by-stage results, especially the use of clean energy for chemical reaction process is highly favored by countries around the world. However, it still has problems to be solved as to how to improve the catalytic activity of PEC technology and realize industrialization. Based on this review and the referenced literature, we propose the problems and research priorities for the future development of PEC technology: (1) According to the current research results, the PEC activity of noble metal-based materials, such as Au, Ag, Pt, and Pd, is stronger than that of most of the elements, however, the noble metals are limited by their high mining cost and low storage capacity, which restrict their development in the field of PEC. In view of this, the future development of PEC is favorable through the mining and use of elements with abundant reserves, such as transition metal elements such as Fe, Co, NI, Cu, and Zn, rare earth elements such as Ce, Ga, and La, as well as carbon materials. These elements are abundantly stored in the earth, and the mining cost is relatively controllable, which is expected to realize industrialization and industrial application. For example, common materials such as GaN, α-Fe2O3, CeO2, BiVO4 and Cu2O are synthesized with simple methods and mild conditions, which are conducive to controlling the cost and realizing mass production. In addition, efforts should be made to develop catalysts with fast reaction kinetics, high selectivity, and good stability, and the synthesis methods should be selected with high yields so that mass production can be realized in industry. (2) Although the use of non-precious metal-based catalysts is beneficial to achieve cost control, however, the catalytic activity of non-precious metal-based catalysts is still inferior to that of precious metal catalysts, which requires the modification of non-precious metal-based catalysts to achieve efficient catalytic processes. For example, by modifying the inherent properties of crystals such as exposed crystal faces, crystal phases, and defects; compounding other materials to form heterojunctions; and forming single atoms on the surface. By using these methods, the catalytic activity of non-precious metal-based materials can be improved so that their performance is comparable to that of precious metal-based catalysts. However, the enhancement of catalytic activity is still a great challenge, so a lot of research and experiments are needed. (3) Although a great deal of work has been done on PEC, however, the reaction mechanism of the PEC process still needs to be explored in depth. Most of the reported work on the reaction mechanism of PEC is still based on pure photocatalysis and pure electrocatalysis, and the influence of the synergistic effect of PEC on the reaction process has not been deeply explored. For example, the influence of the synergistic effect of PEC on the results of overpotential, product selectivity, and reaction yield of the reaction process. This needs to be analyzed in depth from the perspectives of the microstructure of the material, the reaction mechanism, and the reaction energy barriers. (4) Observation of the reaction process is also important. So far, a large amount of work has demonstrated the effect of reaction intermediates on catalytic activity. For example, analyzing the physical phase of a reaction by in situ infrared spectroscopy or in situ Raman can help to understand the catalytic interfaces and active sites, and to monitor the changes in catalysts and intermediates, thus revealing the reaction mechanism. Other in situ techniques such as transmission electron microscopy (TEM), atomic force microscopy (AFM), scanning probe microscopy (SPM), and synchrotron radiation can probe the changes in the interface and structure of materials during catalytic reactions to better understand the conformational relationship between catalyst structure and activity. (5) External reaction conditions also influence the PEC reaction process, such as: pH value, model of the reaction apparatus, reaction temperature, gas pressure and flow rate, and error of the detection device. Although these effects have not been emphasized in the current research work, these factors still have a certain degree of influence on the PEC reaction, so it is important to pay attention to these factors and add these conditions as detailed as possible in the manuscript or SI to provide a reference for others. In conclusion, as a kind of catalytic technology that can save energy and protect the environment, PEC technology still has important research significance and broad application prospect in the face of energy crisis and environmental pollution in the world nowadays, although it faces the challenges of research and development and industrialized application. Gao-Ren Li (College of Materials Science and Engineering, Sichuan University). Prof. Gao-Ren Li received his B.A. degree from East China University of Technology (China) in 2000, and Ph.D. degree from Sun Yat-sen University (China) in 2005. From September 2005 to September 2021, he worked in School of Chemistry, Sun Yat-sen University. Since October 2021, he has been working in College of Materials Science and Engineering, Sichuan University. His current research interests mainly focus on electrocatalysis, especially water splitting and electrochemical conversion of CO2.

coredata.dc:description: Increasing global energy consumption and environmental pollution make the use of new energy sources and environmentally friendly technologies essential to meet the diverse needs of industries. Photoelectrocatalysis is a promising method of utilising solar and electrical energy for various catalytic reactions with significant environmental and energy saving benefits. And photoelectrocatalytic (PEC) oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) are two catalytic reactions with great potential for energy and environmental applications. PEC OER is critical for renewable energy technologies for water oxidation and other related oxidation reactions. PEC CO2RR converts carbon dioxide into high-value products via a catalyst, enabling the rational use of carbon dioxide and the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. Both technologies are efficient, environmentally friendly, and sustainable. However, further research and optimisation are needed to promote the industrial application of both technologies for energy conversion and environmental protection. This paper reviews the research progress of PEC CO2RR and OER catalysts in recent years, including detailed descriptions of catalyst types, reaction mechanisms and performance tests. Finally, the paper considers the future trends and prospects of PEC technology, providing new insights into the technology and research directions for PEC OER and CO2RR catalysts.
